NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, a payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I hereby certify that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended September 30, 1945.

Principal

Dated October 1, 1945

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. Dear Sir:

In checking up with the bank this morning, we find that there was a mistake in the last Quarterly Return of $2.18.

You will notice that cheque No. 332, March 21st, to Johnson & Son, Ltd., is $109.44. This should read $107.26, a difference of $2.18.

The trouble was, that, when issuing the cheque we deducted the $2.18 but when we entered it in the book, we took the figure on the invoice. To make matters worse, this cheque was not returned to the Bank on the morning of March 31st. When we got the Bank Book on May 1st, this item shows as on March 31st.

This item was for house equipment, so to keep matters straight we have deducted the $2.18 from equipment costs, and then from the totals, all the way through to the end of March. The Bank Statement attached to the Quarterly Report will show that the Bank Balance on March 31st was $4991.18. Deducting cheque No. 332 for $107.26 and cheque No. 337 for $20.61, will give true balance of $4863.31.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the change in principalship at the Shubenacadie Residential School. I regret that you have not been previously notified regarding this.

On the FOOD, we have followed the same menus, with shortages and substitutes here and there. We remark, however, that the total for the two years of 1943-44 and 1944-45 combined, is over a Thousand Dollars less than the total for the two previous years.

On FUEL it was necessary for us to import Hard American Coal last year, instead of the usual Welsh hard coal that we had heretofore used. The increased cost per ton, plus the freight and duty, made that much higher.

Generally, while there was a large increase for one year on House Equipment and Farm, the total for the two years is practically the same as the total for the two previous years.

The purchase of an Electrical bread and meat cutter, or slicer, at $310.00 was a necessary and most useful unit added to the kitchen efficiency.

No Canadian household has escaped increased costs during war years and we cannot hope to do better here.

We trust that we have explained matters to your satisfaction, and if there are any further details you wish, please let us know, and we shall gladly send them.

October 18, 1945.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Your letter of September 7th at hand. We are sorry for the delay in answering, but for the past month, we were quite busy with the pump situation.

In reply to your inquiry as to the cause of increased expenditures for 1944-45, over preceding years, May I submit the following table of costs for the last four years.

|        | CLOTHING | FOOD     | FUEL, Etc. | EQUIPMENT | FARM    |
|--------|----------|----------|------------|-----------|---------|
| 1941-42| $360.68  | $477.92  | $764.29    | $205.32   | $791.80 |
| 1942-43| $229.94  | $116.03  | $322.38    | $162.37   | $785.43 |
| 1943-44| $52.99   | $49.59   | $804.13    | $192.26   | $793.83 |
| 1944-45| $43.40   | $735.18  | $470.50    | $207.82   | $506.79 |

The above shows that generally the two years of 1943-44 and 1944-45 combined are not much more costly, and that is the only way to make comparisons.

1943-45 was not a normal year as to costs. We could not secure required amount of clothing, boots, or underwear. Hence we were living from our house supplies, in stock, which are very much depleted at this time. We had only a cost of $52.99 for clothing in that year, while a pair of boots costs $3.00. When we have a chance to purchase needed clothing, then you will have increased costs. All our purchases for house, children, or farm, were more costly during the last year. Dominion statistics are at hand at Ottawa to account for part of the increase.

One item alone, woollen goods for winter skirts, trousers, and outdoor wear, it was impossible to get. When we did procure some last year, it was quite an item. It was only by the most careful use of much material given us by the Military, through Mr. Rice, that our devoted Sisters cut and patched to make things go, and save costs.

Ottawa, December 20, 1945.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, in reference to Victory Bond #L 2 V2579 for $5,000.00, maturing November 1, 1956.

Extensive repairs were required at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School this year, and as the amount necessary was not included in our appropriation, the Principal of the Shubenacadie School, Reverend J. W. Brown, was authorized to proceed with the work needed and pay for it from school funds. It is for this reason that he desires to sell the Bond mentioned.

As the bond is registered in the name of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch and myself consider that the only signature required is that of Father Brown, who is the signing officer for the Shubenacadie School account.

SHUBENACADIE, N. S.,
June 30th, /48.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont., Canada.

Re: Indian Residential School,
SHUBENACADIE, N. S.

I have been advised by Sister Mary Charles, Superior at the captionally noted School, that their finances are at a very low ebb.

It is understood that a Grant is given this School quarterly, and it has been the custom for an advance to be made within the three month period. On checking over the Financial Statement from this School which was forwarded to you on June 29th/48, I noted that the Bank Balance was five dollars ($5.00), so it can be readily seen that an advance is urgently required.

It would be greatly appreciated if an advance of $1,000.00 could be made with the least possible delay, as wages have to be met for the current month.

(H. C. RICH) Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency.

Re: INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

Reference to your telegram of July 6th last, respecting
the financial condition of the captionally noted School.

The Principal, Rev. J. W. Brown advises me that it was
an oversight on his part, that the financial statement did
not bear his signature.

I have gone over his books very carefully and I cannot
find one instance where there was not good judgement used
in the purchase of equipment, supplies, etc. The present
financial condition of this School can be attributed
to the increase costs of living which has gone up from 50%
to 60% within the last year; whereas, the per-capita grant to
a school was only increased by 17%. Wages have been increased
at this Institution by approximately $100.00 by month and the
management have stocked up considerable fuel, feed, etc.,
which will be carried in to the next Academic year.

The wages for the month of May has been paid, but no
salaries have been paid for the month of June.

I would strongly recommend that this Institution be given
an advance grant to meet their current obligations.

H. C. RICE
Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency.

11th April, 1949.

Rt. Rev. Msgr. J.P. Mackey,
Principal,
Shubenacadie Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

Dear Msgr. Mackey:

I have just reviewed your financial statement for the quarter ended March 31st, 1949, for the Shubenacadie Residential School.

It is noted that under the heading "Buildings and Repairs" there is an expenditure of $103.49, and under the heading "House Equipment" there is an expenditure of $304.62. Might I suggest that in future if repairs are required or new equipment is needed, you write to us before incurring the expenditure.

In the case of repairs you would only have to state what is required and give an estimate of the cost. In the case of equipment you would have to list the articles needed, and if they come within the range of the items which we allow, purchase will be made through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. A description of the article, catalogue number, the name of the firm and the cost at which they can be secured should also be supplied. By following this suggestion we could probably save you a considerable amount of money during the course of a year.

As you are aware, we do not always supply articles which you might enter under the heading of equipment,

.....2
but are actually replacement of expendable articles. However, purchase of equipment of a more or less permanent nature will be favourably considered.

I trust that everything is going well at the school, and that you are enjoying good health. Best wishes for Easter, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Province of NOVA SCOTIA.

March 29, 1928.

MEMORANDUM: Dr. Scott.

Tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie; the tenders close at noon of the 30th day of April. If a satisfactory tender is received and a contract awarded we will require the services of a competent Inspector of Construction.

As it takes time for the Civil Service Commission to make the appointment I would recommend that arrangements be made now so that the Inspector's services will be available as soon as the contract is awarded.

ARCHITECT.
Memorandum.

March 30, 1928.

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Tenders are now being invited for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, N.S., and when the contract is awarded we will require the services of a competent Inspector for the work during the construction of the building. We would propose to pay the man employed at the rate of $6.00 per day. As the position is one which comes under the jurisdiction of the Civil Service Commission, it will have to be advertised by them. I would propose to ask them to advertise the position without delay but would like to have a suggestion as to who should be employed. I telephoned Mr. Illsley, M.P., this morning with regard to the matter but was unable to get him as he had left for home.

Deputy Superintendent General.
GOVERNMENT OF CANADA

POSITION VACANT

Applications are invited from residents of Nova Scotia and locality possessing the necessary qualifications for the position of Inspector of Construction (Temporary), Shubenacadie Reserve, N.S., Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Salary $6.00 per day.

Qualifications required: Primary school education; at least two years of supervisory experience in construction work; ability to read and interpret plans and specifications; familiarity with materials and methods of construction; fast and good judgment; integrity. The probable duration of employment will be six months. The appointee for this position should report on or about May 15, 1928.

An eligible list, which will be valid for one year for appointments of this nature, may be established as a result of this competition.

Applications must be in the handwriting of the persons applying (or if otherwise, the reason therefor to be given) and on forms supplied by the Commission, which may be obtained from the office at which this notice is displayed, or from the Secretary, Civil Service Commission, Ottawa, and are to be received by not later than.

Length of residence in the locality must be stated. Applicants must describe the position as indicated above and must not vary description in making application.

According to law, preference is given among candidates possessing the necessary qualifications first to persons who are in receipt of a pension on account of disabilities received as a result of war service, and by reason of such service are unable to continue their pre-war occupation, and who have not been successfully re-established, and secondly, to persons who have been on active service overseas or on the high seas. Candidates must be British subjects and must have resided in Canada at least three years.

Under the provisions of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, 1924, a deduction of five per cent is made from the salary of every permanent employee entering the Service as a contribution to the Superannuation Fund.

Civil Service Commission, Ottawa, Canada. W. FORAN, Secretary

POSITION VACANT

Applications are invited from Residents of the Province of Nova Scotia qualified for the Position of

INSPECTOR OF CONSTRUCTION, TEMPORARY—$6.00 PER DAY

SHUBENACADIE INDIAN SCHOOL, DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
HANTS COUNTY, N.S.

Duties: Under direction, to oversee and inspect assigned portions of construction and repair work to ensure conformity with plans and specifications; to keep records of and make reports on the progress of the work, materials and supplies, and labour costs; if required, to act as construction foreman; to take inventories of supplies; and to perform other related work as required.

Qualifications Required: Primary school education; at least two years of supervisory experience in construction work; ability to read and interpret plans and specifications; familiarity with materials and methods of construction; tact and good judgment; integrity.

Nature of Examination: A rating on Education and Experience will be given from the sworn statements, supporting documents and other evidence submitted by applicants. Candidates must give full particulars regarding their technical training and experience, especially as they bear on the qualifications for and duties of this class of position. To those who qualify an oral examination will be given, if necessary in the opinion of the Commission.

The probable duration of employment will be six months.

The appointee for this position should report immediately after appointment.

Preference will be given to residents of Hants County.

Candidates must be British subjects and must have resided in Canada at least three years.

According to law, preference is given among candidates possessing the necessary qualifications, first to persons who are in receipt of a pension on account of disabilities received as a result of war service, who by reason of such service are unable to continue their pre-war occupation, and who have not been successfully re-established, and secondly, to persons who have been on active service overseas or on the high seas.

Application forms properly filled in must be filed in the office of the Secretary, Civil Service Commission, Ottawa, not later than May 21, 1928. Application forms may be obtained from the Offices of the Employment Service of Canada, from the Post Offices at Halifax, Truro and Yarmouth, N.S., or from the Secretary, Civil Service Commission, Ottawa.

By Order of the Commission,

W. FORAN,
Secretary.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

We wish to report that, on the 20th and 21st instant, we were in Halifax for the purpose of meeting the Roman Catholic Church authorities, concerning the proposed Indian residential school at Shubenacadie and to look into building materials and sources of supply.

We met the committee appointed by His Grace the Archbishop of Halifax, and, after conveying the greetings of the Honourable the Superintendent General and yourself, we explained the Department's proposal. Rev. Father C. E. McManus, of St. Mary's Cathedral, Halifax, Chairman of the committee, gave assurances of their eagerness to cooperate and appeared quite willing to have the proposed institution come under our regular scheme for schools of this class. After going somewhat into details concerning the management and conduct of an Indian residential school, we discussed the service that can be given to the Indian children who might be enrolled there. A set of plans and literature concerning Indian residential schools were left with Father McManus.

It is proposed to secure the Sisters of Charity for the domestic and classroom activity, and we visited their Mother House on the Bedford road, near Halifax. Their institution and the Sisters we met made a very favourable impression and they, too, seemed quite eager to go into Indian work. We left with them also a set of plans and literature concerning residential schools. The Mother General of the Order is at present in Western Canada and she and her staff arranged to visit the Blood Indian Residential School, to get firsthand information concerning its conduct.

Supt. of Indian Education.

On Tuesday, the 19th instant, we arrived at Shubenacadie, N.S., to examine properties there for the proposed Indian residential school. J. L. Ilsley, B.A., of Kentville, N.S., for Hants-Ling, met us there and assisted until a final selection was made. At the outset, we had a preliminary look at the various sites that had been brought to our attention by letter, and, without much hesitation, we soon confined our interest to the Ettor and Gay farms, which were carefully examined. Certain local persons with some influence were desirous that the Davis property be included in the final examination, but Mr. Ilsley and ourselves could not agree that it was suitable enough to be worthy of comparison with the other two.

It was considered advisable to proceed to Halifax for the 20th and 21st, for the purpose of meeting the church authorities and to look into building materials and sources of supply. The final selection of a site was postponed until Friday, the 22nd. On that date the Ettor and Gay farms were examined with considerable care. While the first named property appeared to possess more possibilities as a productive farm—a much wider choice of acreage being available for purchase—from every other angle the Gay property was more suitable.

The Gay property is situated one-half mile from the station at Shubenacadie—immediately on the outskirts of the village. The site is reached by a good road leading directly from the village—a distinct advantage over other properties, in that it is not necessary to cross the railroad when travelling to and from Shubenacadie. It is pointed out that this railroad is the main line of the C.P.R., over which there is heavy traffic, and the importance of this to the staff and children will be understood. The farm consists of approximately 65 acres of cultivated upland, 50 acres of woodland, 10 of which have already been cleared sufficiently for pasture, and 17 acres of meadow which produces hay perennially without attention. The properties surrounding it appear to be clean and well-located. We consider this Gay farm, which consists of about 65 acres, more or less, large enough for the needs of the proposed institution for some time to come. The farm is to be clean and productive and is in one block. It should be mentioned that a fresh water lake, suitable for boating and fishing, just touches the northern boundary of the Gay farm.

On this property is an ideal building site which commands a view of the countryside in all directions. The building will be seen from the railroad and...
five roads running in and out of Shubenacadie. The site selected also provides ample opportunity for excellent drainage and water supply, the Shubenacadie river being less than 100 yards from the spot for the building. Electric current and telephone connection are available.

We wish to point out that it was impossible to locate a building site on the Etter property which was at all close to the railroad or main highway, and the drainage facilities were not at all comparable with those of the Gay property. This also applies with more force to the Davis property, but, in addition, the Davis property's only possible site for the building was immediately over disfiguring gravel pits and generally rough ground. It was represented to us that a siding which was close to the Davis property would be a big advantage. However, this feature was not worthy of serious thought as all materials would have to be unloaded from the cars into a vehicle and hauled up a difficult grade to the building. The Gay property, without railroad to cross and only a few hundred yards farther from a railroad station, had the distinct advantage of being near a post office and business community. We were warned by certain interested parties that the road leading to the Gay property, which happens to be the main road to Maitland, was flooded at certain seasons of the year. We made several enquiries from independent sources on this connection and we learned that the road was flooded for an hour or two a day in the spring of certain years only, but that it was not impassable even when flooded.

Mr. S. J. Etter wanted $13,500 for his farm, which consists of 270 acres. A lot of the value of this property is tied up in the buildings, the most important of which would have to be removed in the event of an Indian residential school being erected there. Mr. George Gay, in his written offer to Mr. Indian Agent Lawlor, asked $9,000 for his 130 acres, and was able to secure from him an option on the property at $7,000, provided he be allowed to harvest this year's crop. He promised to do the fall ploughing and otherwise prepare the fields for next year's farming operations.

We wish to recommend that the farm of George Gay be surveyed at an early date, with a view to determining not only the exact size of the property but also the best building site. If everything is found as has been represented to us and the title is satisfactory, we believe it advisable to arrange the purchase. In our opinion it is easily the best property near Shubenacadie for an Indian residential school. When title is being searched, it should be ascertained what privileges the owners have in connection with the lake that touches the property and if there is a right of way around its southern extremity.

Some time ago, approximately one-eighth of an acre of this farm was sold for the site of a residence. Three
or four years ago, the purchaser, Mr. Allan S. Etter, erected a residence, which would make a very suitable home for the farm instructor and other male members of the staff of the proposed school. This residence and lot, which is situated on the entrance road to the property, can be purchased for $4,000, which sum is less than would be required to erect a suitable farmer's residence. We strongly recommend that this property, also, be purchased.

Supt. of Indian Education.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

During the early part of the Summer, your Architect brought the plans of the building to be erected for the accommodation of the Indians at Shubenacadie, with the request that we study them and make such suggestions as would be acceptable to the work. We regret that we have delayed in returning the plans to your department until now.

Our General Superior being absent during the greater part of the Summer, must be our excuse for keeping the plans so long. We are enclosing a list of the suggestions that might be acceptable for the better government of the work in this residential school. It is well in the beginning of this undertaking to have the conveniences that we think necessary in order to make the work more satisfactory.

Let us state here the points under consideration:

1. Would it not be well to have two (2) doors at least, in each of the dormitories on the top story?

2. The wash-tables in the middle of these dormitories would seem to be unsanitary. They certainly would not be helpful to the discipline of the dormitory. Might these wash-tables be placed in the center of the toilet-rooms. In this case, these rooms would have to be made larger, or would it be desirable to cut off from the end of each dormitory, lavatories for this purpose? This would permit the children to be trained to better advantage.

3. Would it not be advisable to have fire-escapes from the upper dormitories instead of from the staff-room?

4. It is desirable to have closets on the Girls' and Boys' side of each floor for brushes, brooms, etc.

5. The children will have unused clothing, as they must have at least some changes. There does not seem to be much provision made for the storing of this clothing.

6. In the basement in each of the recreation-rooms some provision should be made for the children's boots and rubbers. Perhaps for these small cubicles might be made along the side of the wall and these could be used for seats also.

The General Fair Wage Clause calls for the observance of the rates of wages and hours of labour of the different classes of workmen required which are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract, for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed, and if there be no current rates or hours in the district, then fair and reasonable rates and hours. I shall be pleased, therefore, if you will give us word shortly before the time that tenders are called for this school building, in order that a schedule may be furnished to you for the above purpose.

All mechanics, labourers, or other persons who perform labour in the construction of the work hereby contracted for, shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed for the character or class of work in which they are respectively engaged, and if there be no current rates in such district, then fair and reasonable rates, and shall work such hours as are customary in the trade in the district where the work is carried on, or if there be no custom of the trade as respects hours in the district, then fair and reasonable hours, unless for the protection of life and property, or for other cause shown to the satisfaction of the Minister of Labour, longer hours of service are required. The Minister of Labour may at any time and from time to time determine for the purposes of this contract, what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages, and the current or fair and reasonable hours, and may from time to time rescind, revoke, amend or vary any such decision, provided that his determination and any amendment or variation shall not be operative prior to the period of three months immediately preceding the date thereof. Where there are special circumstances which in the judgment of the Minister of Labour make it expedient that he should do so, he may, in the manner and subject to the provisions hereinabove set forth, decide what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages for overtime, and what is the proper classification of any work for the purposes of wages and hours. Dear Mr. Boyd:

I was pleased to learn that through your effort there is a likelihood of an institution for Indians being established here, and regret that I did not at the time know of your visit. I do not wish to butt in anywhere, but I presume that the first thing in your mind is a suitable location, at a reasonable price, for the popularity of the movement will depend much on the location.

I need not say to you that Shubenacadie Village, situated on the C.N.R., and on the main highway from Halifax to Truro, exactly in the centre of the Province, the best farming community in the province, with excellent connection by Rail, Main highways, Stages, Telegraph and Telephone with all parts must be a desirable location, and the Indian Reserve of some 1000 acres is only 5 miles distant.

As a lifelong resident of the place, and for many years past Appraiser for the Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation, I have perhaps a better knowledge of the farms here, and their values than others could have, and I have no axe to grind.

I do know however if you can secure a suitable location and build this institution near our Town, and close to Ry Depot, Post Office, Tel and Tel offices, Churches etc. that it would mean much to the appearance and popularity of the Institution, and to the future of this Town.

I can well believe that a location on the main highway with a good elevation, ample water supply and opportunity for sewerage and with a good view would be the ideal, and several such can be obtained here within ½ mile of the Ry Depot and Post Office.

While I repeat that I have no axe to grind, and my first thought is the best interests of the Institution and this Town and community, I beg to say that I have one of the finest farms in the Province, within sight of the Town, less than ½ mile from Ry Depot, on the main highway, at a good elevation overlooking the Shubenacadie River and in full view from the Railway, most excellent situation, splendid soil, about two weeks earlier than most farms, ample water supply for an Institution and sewerage easily available, 32 acres of the renowned Shubenacadie River marsh, the most prolific and easily cultivated of farm lands and yielding a continual annual crop of hay without cultivation, small orchard, a splendid flat for an institutional athletic grounds, a large barn capable of housing 50 head of cattle and storing 150 tons hay and located where in my judgement it would not interfere with your other buildings.

I only bought farm last year. It had been rather neglected, but cut 120 Tons Hay and some grain crop but I
expect in two years to be making it produce 200 tons hay besides other crops.

The whole farm contains around 400 acres, but I would sell the front or cultivated portion say 150 to 200 acres and retain the rear end woodlands for myself.

Now all this does not sound as though I have no axe to grind. But the fact remains that I am not anxious to sell it. Besides there are a number of other places near the town, which can be bought and one or two of them at low prices. S.J. Ritter, George Gay, Fred Ritter, Joseph Fleming, all have good locations and are worth your while looking over to get the best for the money.

My farm could easily be made one of the show places of the country, the view of and from the farm cannot be excelled.

The marsh alone is valued $200 per acre or $6400, but if you would not want the marsh I will keep it, and sell the upland portion, or any part of that.

While as I have said I am not anxious to sell, I am very anxious that you get a property that will suit you entirely and within 4 mile of our town, as I know that would mean a great deal to the future of the community.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Mr. D.B. Lawlor, local Indian Agent has waited on me and inspected my farm.

In the absence of definite knowledge as to your requirements, I have drawn up a rough sketch and description showing a number of different proposals for sale, and have told him further, that I will subdivide farm in any other way that will meet your wishes.

While Mr. Lawlor perhaps would not consider himself competent to declare emphatically on the quality of the farm, I know he was favourably impressed.

He certainly was with regard to the location, building sites, and particularly the water supply and facilities for the sewage which I pointed out to him, and which are noted on the description I gave him for forwarding.

He at least was surprised when after inspecting some others, I showed him A REAL FARM.

I pointed out to him that the soil was different from any other he had seen being a deep sandy loam, free from stones, easily cultivated and very productive.

This was easily demonstrated on the ploughed grounds and growing crops.

I might repeat that for a number of years I have been appraiser for The Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation, and know something of farms and farm values. I have appraised many of the farms in this district, and you can believe that when I bought a year ago I bought what I knew to be the best one.

I intended keeping it but continued sickness of members of my family make it advisable for me to sell.

While the matter of your choice of the several offers I have made, is immaterial to me, if you will permit me to suggest, as a practical man, your best purchase is lots No. 1 and 2—90 acres at $6,500 inasmuch as the Barn on these lots, is not old, is an up-to-date plan and with slight repair and alteration would be A 1 and could not be replaced for $4500.

I have no hesitation in saying this would be the best 90 acre farm in Nova Scotia.

If you wish to add the Marsh Lot No. 4—34½ acres at $3000, or a total of $12,500 you would have 125 more farm without any any superior in Canada.

This Marsh land is valued at not less than $150 per acre. I would not sell it separately for less than $4500. I am offering to you in combination with other lots at $3000.
It is the finest of agricultural land suitable for any crop by cultivation and yielding an annual hay crop without any cultivation or fertilization and has been doing so to my personal knowledge for upwards of 50 years.

Generally, let me say, without making any comparison with other farms available,

You do not have to cross a Railway track (which must be objectionable) to get to my farm.

Its frontage is on the main Provincial highway.

The Soil is a deep loam free from stone, easily cultivated and very productive.

Its location cannot be excelled. It is in the exact centre of the Province within ½ mile of Railway Depot, Post and Telegraph Office, Schools, Churches, Public Hall, County Exhibition and Athletic Grounds.

It has ample water supply and opportunity for inexpensive sewerage, to the River, excellent building sites and the view of and from the farm cannot be excelled.

The prices quoted are less than actual value. You may buy cheaper farms but not of this size, location or quality.

Looking to the future of the Institution, in view of the location, quality and facilities, initial expenditure of a thousand or two dollars extra is nothing.

The large Indian Reserve is within 5 miles.

Last year notwithstanding neglect of former owner this farm gave me 120 tons hay besides other crops, the growing crop on it today is worth upwards of £1200.

Within two years if I keep it I will make it yield much more.

Finally I am offering a square deal. I am not enhancing values in any of the different proposals I have made, on the other hand I am offering at very low figures.

My cards are on the table and while from personal reasons I am anxious to sell, I am not altogether governed by self interest but as an old resident of the community who has always taken part in movements for its benefit, I am putting forward the proposal that I know to be best for the community, and for the future success and popularity of your Institution.

I leave the matter in your hands.

Yours truly,

Hon. Charles Stewart,
Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr came to Shubenacadie last Tuesday and I met them there. I visited the four proposed sites with them. They went to Halifax without making a definite selection and returned yesterday and selected the Gay property. This selection is satisfactory to me.

I did not in any way influence or try to influence the decision of Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr believing that they should get the best site available in view of the large amount of money to be spent for construction. Mr. Ferrier, speaking to me by phone last night, said that some arrangement was made with Gay and his son to work on or look after the property next summer. Gay and his son are Conservatives and I am inclined to think that any such arrangement would be undesirable from the political standpoint and should not be confirmed by yourself. The payment of government money to Conservatives is resented by Liberal workers in this province, and it occurred to me shortly after Mr. Ferrier told me this had been arranged it might mean trouble. I found Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr very reasonable and their modus operandi very satisfactory in every way, and I am not in any way complaining. I trust, however, that any arrangement they made to employ either Gay or his son is merely tentative, as I am sure it was. My present feeling is that no agreement to employ the Gays should be entered into. The selection of the Gay site is acceptable to several of the leading Liberals, as they are interest in the property as mortgagees, creditors or otherwise.

The selection of the Gay property was bitterly resented by Hon. B.B. Fulmer, the leading man in our party in the district, who called me up last night and indulged in much menacing talk about the support I would lose next election. I am satisfied that he is practically alone in his dissatisfaction with the site. The site that he offered was according to Mr. Ferrier and Mr. Orr entirely unsuitable and I agreed with them. Fulmer will criticize
me and talk a lot because we are buying from a Tory. However, I am satisfied and I would not on any account alter the selection now. I would like, however, to be consulted in detail about any supplementary purchases of property that take place in the vicinity and about any proposed employment of Gay and his son. I do not want to give Pulmer a real ground for grievance.

I would appreciate it if you would advise me promptly as to the government's intentions in respect of the matters I have mentioned in this letter.

Yours truly,

J.L. Ilsley

THE ULTRA-VIOLET TRANSMISSION OF VARIOUS NEW GLASSES AND WINDOW GLASS SUBSTITUTES AS COMPARED WITH THAT OF COMMON WINDOW GLASS:

This letter circular is issued in response to numerous inquiries for information on the transmissive properties of new glasses and organic substitutes for window glass for use in solariums, sun parlors, schools, homes, office buildings, animal houses, and greenhouses.

The visible rays of light are comprised between the approximate wave length of 760 μm in the red and 400 μm in the violet. Wave lengths longer than 760 μm are called infra-red, and those shorter than 400 μm, ultra-violet. Though the average eye is not sensitive to wave lengths shorter than 400 μm such rays actually exist in the light of the sun, extending down to a wave length a little more or a little less than 300 μm, depending on the time of day, season of year, latitude, altitude and clearness of atmosphere.

Since ordinary window glass shuts out the ultra-violet rays below about 310 μm, much attention has been given of late to the production of special glasses, transparent to the shortest wave lengths which the atmosphere permits the sun to furnish us. This letter circular gives the results of ultra-violet transmission tests which have been made at the Bureau of Standards upon a number of such special glasses and common window glass.

TOTAL TRANSMISSION OF VARIOUS GLASSES FOR THOSE ULTRA-VIOLET SOLAR RAYS TO WHICH COMMON WINDOW GLASS IS OPAQUE

Using a filter method, direct measurements with sunlight as source, have been made during the noon hours of especially clear days from April to December, 1927.

These measurements covered the solar spectral region to which common window glass is opaque (below about 310 μm). Table I gives for that region the total transmission found for the following specimens:

SPECIAL TRANSMISSION OF VARIOUS GLASSES FOR THE ULTRA-VIOLET RAYS

A second and more reliable method of measuring the relative transparency of a specimen of glass to ultra-violet light is to determine its spectral transmission curve, wave length by wave length. Curves of this description are shown in the accompanying illustration. These curves were obtained by means of an artificial source of light (quartz mercury arc) giving a line spectrum richer in ultra-violet than the solar spectrum.

By means of these spectral transmission curves an estimate of the relative transmissions of the various specimens for rays shut out by common window glass, may be obtained by reading from the curves the values of the transmission at 302 μ— the wave length of an intense mercury line, of convenient value for making such tests. SOLARIZATION

Helioglass, Vitaglass and Cel-o-glass have been found to decrease in transmission at 302 μm and neighboring wave lengths (295 to 310 μm) by exposure to ultra-violet radiation from the sun, quartz mercury arc, and carbon arc. The rate of change is much more rapid with the arc than with the sun and varies also with the different glasses.

Vitaglass has been on the market the longest, hence concerning this glass we are able to give the most information on solarization. A sample which had been in a hospital window in Rhode Island for a year was found to have a transmission of 25 per cent. at 302 μm (for thickness = 2.3 mm). Further exposure to the quartz mercury arc reduced the transmission but little, showing that solarization was complete.

Exposure in Washington of a sample (t = 2.35 mm) of Vitaglass directly to the sun for 123 hours (between 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. during June, July, and August) decreased the transmission from 47 to 35 per cent. Our tests show that the greatest decrease in transmission occurs during the first few weeks exposure. The average transmission of Vitaglass at 302 μm after complete degeneration by the mercury arc is about 25 per cent. for a thickness of 2.3 mm.

Helioglass has not been on the market for a sufficient length of time to obtain a complete solarization test. Two samples each of Helioglass and Vitaglass, exposed simultaneously to the sun in October to December, were found to have decreased in transmission at about the same rate. The average transmission of Helioglass at 302 μm after complete degeneration by the mercury arc is about 30 per cent. for a thickness of 2.3 mm.

Corex glass appears to undergo no appreciable change in transmission when exposed to solar radiation. For example, a sample of cathedral finish Corex which had been in a greenhouse roof in New York for 14 months was found to have, as nearly as could be measured on that kind of surface, the same transmission as a new sample. It was then polished plane and found to have a transmission of 89.5 per cent. at 302 μm, while the average transmission for new samples as given in Table 2, is 89.

On the other hand, exposure to a quartz mercury arc causes a very marked decrease in the transmission.
Cel-o-glass (cellulose acetate) becomes opaque at 302 μμ, and shorter wavelengths, after 25 hours exposure to the quartz mercury arc. A sample that was exposed to the sun for 400 hours during the months of April to October, decreased but little in transparency at 302 μμ. On the other hand, samples that transmitted 30 per cent. at 302 μμ, when new, transmitted only 5 to 10 per cent. at this wave length after being exposed on the side of a building continuously day and night for 8 months, April to December, showing that the change in transparency may be owing to the varying conditions of the weather.

Quartz-lite is not appreciably affected by sunlight. Exposure to the quartz mercury arc decreases its transmission slightly (measured at 313 μμ).

Common Window Glass is also slightly decreased in transmission by exposure to the quartz mercury arc but changes inappreciably in sunlight.

THICKNESS

The thinner the glass, the greater in general will be its transparency to ultra-violet rays. Considerations of strength, however, set a limit to an indefinite reduction in thickness. Commercial samples have been submitted for test with a thickness of less than 1 mm (1/25 inch). We feel sure you will have heard of this wonderful glass but, in case you have not, we take the liberty of writing you in a general way and enclosing to you literature which will give you some important facts in connection with this healthful glass.

It will no doubt interest you to know that we are manufacturing "Lamplough Vita Glass" at our factories in England and are carrying stocks at all our Depots throughout Canada.

Briefly we would state: the Ultra Violet Rays of the sun will not pass through common window glass nor as much of the Infra-Red, or heat rays. The former rays contribute largely to good health while the latter are beneficial on account of their warmth. There are several makes of glass which it is claimed function in the same way but VITA glass is the original. It has been subjected to a series of tests over the last three years and has been proved to fulfill all that is claimed of it.

VITA Sheet Glass $1.00 per foot up to one thousand feet.

Dear Sir:-

Re: Shubenacadie Residential School.

On behalf of Rhodes Curry, from whom I have the sub-contract for the Structural Steel and Cast Iron work, beg to submit for your approval details of same.

Where the size of columns is not shown I have worked out the necessary sizes to take the super-imposed loads.

Regarding the beams in the wings, these are shown in some places as 15" - 32# I Beams, and as this weight of 15" Beam is not rolled, I had to check up further, and noting that 2 x 10" spruce joists at 16" centres are good for a total load of 130# per sq. ft. on the spans such as on your building, also further noting that a 12" - 32# I Beam at the spans and spacing as on your building will take a total load of 125# per sq. ft. of floor, and furthermore that this loading is approximately the standard for this type of building, concluded that you intended to use the 13" - 32# Beam and that the 15" was a slip on the part of your draughtsman when tracing.

As they have already begun work on the job and will be needing the steel very shortly, would appreciate it very much if you would wire me should these details meet with your approval, as I have to order the steel from the Mills and we are so far away down here that it takes a long time to obtain deliveries. The columns of course will be cast and machined in Halifax, so that if there are any changes which you might want made on the columns, which would not affect the length of the beams, would appreciate if you would wire through your approval of the beam portion so that I might get same ordered.

Trusting the details submitted may meet with your approval.

Yours very truly,

WHN/S.

I have a letter from Robert Cass of Shubenacadie of which I enclose a copy. I wish you would very carefully consider this proposal. If, without any or much additional expenses, your pipe could be made available for fire protection, it would be a splendid thing for the Village. Dear Mr. Ilsley:

The Engineers were here yesterday, and surveyed at the Indian Farm for the water supply for the institution, and are taking it from the Lake just adjoining and partly on the farm. They are making plans of course only sufficient for the Institution, a pumping station with say a 4 inch pipe which would be adequate for that according to the Engineers.

It would be a great thing if they could be induced to make this large enough (say a six inch pipe) to supply water for the village here for fire protection and other services. Not being an incorporated town, but a part of the municipality, the village is not now in a position to make any definite proposals, and would have to call a citizens meeting and so on, and it would take a little time to get shaped up. It would not be a terribly extravagant thing for the Dept. to put in a plant adequate for all future needs of the Institution and the village as well. It would certainly be a most popular move for you if you could bring this about or even to delay the plans and work until negotiations could be had looking forward to this.

Better get in touch with Ottawa at once and at least get them to consider the matter, and perhaps you could get some proposal from them that we could put before a citizens meeting, which would at least show that you were trying to do something for the community at every opportunity, and if nothing ever came of it you would have credit for the move.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Robert Gass.
December 12, 1928.

Dear Mr. Ilsley,-

I have given most careful attention to your letter of the 30th ultimo with enclosure from Mr. Robert Gass, in which you deal with the proposal to add to our water supply system at the Shubenacadie school in order to accommodate the town and provide for them a fire protection system. I doubt very much the advisability of the Department becoming involved in a scheme of that kind. We would have to provide a pumping plant much larger than would be required for the school including a larger elevated storage tank. The cost of installation would be correspondingly increased; this increase could hardly be charged to public funds and would have to be met in some way by the town and the town would also be put to considerable expense in laying a pipe line from the elevated tank to the town, with hydrants and the necessary hose and equipment. We would have been glad to consider this proposed plan but taking into consideration the cost of installation and the cost of operation it seems to me wise to say that we do not consider the plan favourably.

Yours sincerely,

J. L. Ilsley, Esq., M.P.,

Dear Sir:

Re hardwood flooring, Indian School, Shubenacadie. May say when we were estimating this job we figured on using No.1 grade hardwood flooring, which we presumed was your intention to have used in a building of that sort, for School purposes. The grading rule for No.1 is as follows:

"No.1 - 25/32 inch and thicker, will admit of tight, sound knots and slight imperfections in dressing, but must lay without waste. Standard lengths in all widths in this grade shall be trimmed 15 to 16 feet; the proportion of lengths 15 to 34 feet inclusive shall be what the stock will produce up to 40 percent".

This makes a real good floor. The wearing qualities are just the same as the clear grade. When it is laid it is hard to tell the difference.

Your Inspector interprets the specification as calling for Clear. We did not interpret the specification that way and consequently we figured on using No.1 grade, and if we are forced to use the Clear grade it will cost $300.00 more than we figured, and you really will get no better floor.

I have used a lot of the No.1 grade in my own house and find it makes a first class job. We have also used it in Schools and other Institutions.

We intend placing the order for this flooring right away and would like to have your decision at your earliest convenience.

Presume you are as familiar with the grading of hardwood flooring as we are. May say the sound knots in No.1 are very few. May find an occasional pencil knot in a board.

Yours very truly,

Replying to your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the hardwood flooring specified for the Indian School at Shubenacadie, the specifications call for "first grade" birch or maple and this is the flooring that you will be expected to install.

You probably know that on January 1st, 1928, there was a change made in the classification grading of hardwood flooring. After this date clear flooring was to be known as first grade. First grade flooring shall have one face practically clear but colour no defect. Green or dark streaks not over 1/6" wide or 3" long or its equivalent and small defects which can be readily removed by the ordinary method of scraping after the floor had been laid, permitted.

This grade must have one face free from all shake and shock. Lengths 2 to 16 feet but not over 15 percent under 3½ feet.

Dear Sir:

On account of being delayed by non-delivery of material, it will be impossible for us to have this building completed by the time specified.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of Nov. 6th with reference to survey for Pipe Line in connection with the proposed water supply for the College building, I would say that I have made a preliminary survey and think it advisable before going further to submit the following as to existing conditions, in order that the decision as to location be made with full knowledge as to the situation.

I am sending you under separate cover a Blue Line Print of that portion of the property lying between the Shubenacadie - Maitland Main Public Road and the River, on which is shown, roughly, two alternative locations.

Your letter conveys the impression that the proposed pipe line is to enter the Lake where the shore is within the boundaries of the college property.

Under ordinary conditions I would have assumed that this had been decided upon and have disregarded the second location which, as will be noted, involves crossing a part of the adjoining farm owned by the Brothers Snide. It has also occurred to me that, owing to the fact that my Plan of the College property shows only a small portion of the Lake, a mistaken idea may have been formed as to its size, and location with
reference to the College property. For this reason, I have thought it advisable to submit this memo and await further instructions before making the final location.

The location marked "A" - "B" - "C" as shown, is entirely upon, and takes the water from that portion of the Lake which is within the boundaries of, the College Property.

The distance by this line is 1900 feet, assuming an approximately direct line and reasonable distance from the shore to point of intake. This last should be determined by soundings for the depth of water and observation of the effect on the water of drainage entering from the main road which passes near the Lake at this point.

The rise of the ground from the water level at this point is such that the pump house must be located practically at the shore, see point "A" on Plan. The tank will require to be at the point marked "B" distant about 1000 feet from "A" at which point the elevation is about three feet above the floor of Boiler Room, which is 29 feet above the lake level as on the date of survey, which may be regarded as ordinary high water. The pipe from A to B can be straight with a practically uniform grade. The ground is clear and there is no rock.

From "B" to the building the ground first falls to an elevation of approximately 18 feet above the Lake Level, then rises to the building.

If this line is adopted it will probably not be considered advisable to place the Tank near the building as suggested in your letter, as to do so would necessitate either pumping over the ridge and through the hollow or carrying the pipe line at a considerably greater length around the southern side of the hill in a curve. (See the dotted line "C - D" - "A").

In any case, with this line the Pump house must be at the lake.

Having no information as to the estimated daily consumption, capacity of tank, or size of the pipe to be used, I am not able to say anything as to what protection from frost will be required for the tank.

If this is to be a consideration it can, of course, be more conveniently provided for if the tank is located as your letter suggests, in the rear of the buildings and near the Boiler Room. It should, however, be mentioned that owing to the steep slope and somewhat "springy" nature of the original surface here which has been built up with the loose clay and earth excavated from the foundation of the building,
it will be necessary to pay greater attention to the foundation for the tank if placed at that point than if located elsewhere.

As has been made clear, the adoption of this route, while having the advantage of being entirely upon the property of the College, and absence of curve in the pipe line, has the disadvantage of requiring the Pump House to be at the Lake, and the tank at about 900 feet from the College Building. There is also the question as to whether the water at this point of intake will be found as pure as if taken further from the road, as at the point "F".

The alternative route marked "C"-"E" "F" as proposed involves crossing the Snide farm, for a distance, between the College Property boundary and the Lake shore, of 425 feet. This line which leaves the lake at or near the point marked "F" passes over an approximately level surface, through and along the margin of a swamp with a gradual rise which reaches an elevation above the Lake level of 14 feet at point "E", 1100 feet from the Lake, at which point the Pump House can be located.

From "E" to the building at "C", the distance as measured on the survey tangents is 718 feet to the corner of the Boiler Room at the rear of the building at or near which the Tank will be located.

This line is open and the excavation cost, while slightly greater than that on line "A"-"B"-"C", owing to the necessity for greater depth where it crosses two small ridges, will not be materially greater, and may possibly be offset by the somewhat shorter pipe line called for.

As shown, the line is not straight but the curve, if thought objectional, can be eliminated by alteration in direction at the pump.

Without knowing the size and type of pipe which will be used, I am unable to estimate to what extent the friction through the 1100 feet will affect the lift.

I have spoken to Mr. Snide as to the pipe line crossing his property and he has expressed himself as not opposed to it or in any way inclined to put obstacles in the way. He mentioned as a reasonable compensation $100.00, but afterward told me he was not disposed to "Bargain" and would accept any reasonable compensation. I am of the opinion that he will accept $50.00.
As will be apparent the advantages of this location are slightly shorter distance and its being possible to locate the Pump House within 700 feet of the College and the Tank as close as may be required, also the, probably, more desirable point of intake.

The disadvantage being that it is in part on the adjoining property.

I have not thought it necessary at this stage to make more than a preliminary survey, or to prepare a profile of the two routes. If you will advise me as to which location has been selected I will at once complete the Survey and forward plan showing details.

I remain,

I beg to report that on the 10th and 11th of this month I made an inspection of the new Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, N.S. While there I gathered the information necessary to lay out the water supply system for the building and I beg to submit the following particulars.

Adjoining the School property is a small lake indicated on the plan as Snide Lake and located approximately 2000 feet N.E. of the School building. An analysis of the water from this lake was made in the laboratory of the Provincial Department of Health at Halifax and found to be satisfactory for domestic purposes. The possibility of using a well as a source of supply was considered, but it was found on inquiry that well water in the vicinity of Shubenacadie was hard and unpalatable. Snide Lake is, therefore, recommended as a source of supply.

Before the most economical system could be decided upon it was necessary to ascertain if a continuous supply of electric power would be available at the School. On inquiring it was found that the local Electric Light Co. has been taken over by the Avon River Power Co. and they will be in a position to supply a continuous 24 hour service after July 1st of this year. With continuous electric power available a water supply system incorporating a pneumatic tank and automatic power pumps is recommended.

The layout of the proposed water supply system provides for a pump house, located approximately 700 feet to the rear of the School building and 1100 feet from the Lake. At this point the elevation of the pump house will be 14 feet above the water level of the lake and 15 feet below the basement level of the School. The suction pipe will be 5" galvanized steel and the force main 4" galvanized steel pipe. The pumping equipment
will consist of a Fairbanks Morse No 4340 self-oiling Typhoon power pump, belted to a ball-bearing motor, both mounted on steel base. This pump has a working pressure of 65 pounds and a capacity of 5000 gallons per hour.

For fire protection a Fairbanks Morse Centrifugal pump No 3264, 4" with direct connected motor will be provided. The pump house will be 14' x 16' of brick construction and will house the pumps and a 4' x 16' pneumatic tank. The building will be heated by a stove.

The system contemplated will provide an ample supply of good water for all domestic purposes and an adequate fire protection.

I would recommend that the installation be carried out by day labour under the supervision of Mr. Crowell, who has acted as Inspector of Construction on the work. Mr. Crowell is competent to supervise this work and the day labour basis will be the most economical way of having the system installed. All materials required will be purchased by the Department.

I enclose herewith copy of the agreement to be signed by Messrs. Snide. This is for your approval.

I have not as yet submitted it to Mr. Snide, but in discussing the matter a few days since he suggested the clause providing for payment for damage should it be found necessary at some future time when the land was under crop, to open the line or use the right of way in such manner as to cause additional damage.

I have included that condition as it seems to me to be not unreasonable.

You will note also that I have mentioned the width of the strip or right of way over which the privilege is given as ten feet which should be ample for all purposes.
I have also endeavoured to generally phrase the agreement so as to be capable of being interpreted as a perpetual Lease, otherwise I think it would be necessary to carry a termination clause which in this case would be undesirable.

Dear Mr. Crowell,

We are in receipt of your affidavit.

Note what you say regarding furnishing of Indian School.

I have been confined to my house with a bad cold all this week hence the delay in answering.

I was under the impression that we had done everything in connection with School building that was called for in the specification and shown on plan.

I do not know what more we can do to the basement floor other than what has been done.

I never supposed for a moment that a floor of that kind would be wanted. In fact in the Master Builder's specification the warking is a warking is a separate process and can be specified by the Architect if so desired. We did not figure on doing that class of work and if we are compelled to wark that floor the same as a first class job in a private residence it will cost us a lot of money that we did not figure on. As I have already explained to you, the contract was taken at a very fine figure and owing to the delays which were caused.
beyond our control, there is no profit in the contract for us.

We want to do what is right, but I think any builder will bear me out in saying that we have no right in doing anything further to the basement floors.

I consider we have given a first class job in that respect. Re. the leaks in the roof, I am writing Mr. Doucette and trust he will go to Shuter & Shooter at once and try to make everything satisfactory. We would make the building tight no matter if it had been taken over or not.

Regarding the platform you speak of in the rear of the building. Was it two taken up with Mr. Burns? I do not understand why this was done was left off if it was supposed to be put there. I will take the matter up with him - or would you kindly have it done and send us the bill. I do not imagine it will amount to much.

As you know we have some $20,000 tied up in the building, besides our certified cheque and it is quite necessary that we get relieved from our obligation as soon as possible so as to get our money.

If you can do anything to expedite the taking over the building, I assure you it will be a great obligation to us.

Sir,

Melvin, 6 Cunard St., Halifax, who quoted a price of $1,356.00 for 12 ft. Standard Lap Welded Galv. Dear Sir:

Enclosed you will please find time sheets for water installation from June 26th. to July 13th. There has been other expenses for material in connection with the pump house, including lumber, gravel, buckets, etc. The freight on the gravel has been paid, that accounts for the cheque number being 1, 2, 4, not 1, 2, 3. All ploughing carting etc. has been done by the farm horses, but not charged. If you wish that to be charged against the water installation it can easily be done as we have the time of such work. Again the cheque for paying the men did not come till July 6th. and as the men were asking for their money before that I advanced the money to Mr. Crowell covering the amount of the cheques No. 1 and 2. The balance as you will see is $388.95, which will not be sufficient to cover the wages for the next week and the cost of material, so will you please let us have some more money. I have opened a second account at the bank for this work, so I hope I won't get things mixed up. When I have the receipts for the material purchased I will forward two copies to you. I have only one receipt for freight bills, will it be necessary to have three copies?

Please let me have a supply of envelopes of all sizes and color.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Reference to progress on the pipe line for water supply to the Indian College at Shubenacadie, N. S.

I wrote you some ten days since but through an oversight the letter was not mailed during my absence, of upwards of a week, from the Office. The letter referred to was in substance as follows:

Mr. Crowell has at the time of last inspection almost completed the laying of the Pipe and had the foundation and floor of the Pump House in, and walls about two feet above the floor.

Some trouble and consequent delay was caused due to the walls of the excavation caving, but this was not of a serious nature and once the pipe was on the ground caused no delay.

I thought it advisable to ask Mr. Crowell to leave the Pipe uncovered for a short time in order that we might note whether there was any tendency to sink or rest unevenly or in such a way as to cause undue strain, owing to soft bottom in sections of the trench.

This will not in any way inconvenience or impede Mr. Crowell as he had intended, (properly I think) to defer covering in the pipe until after the Pump had been installed and the system thoroughly tested.

This should be in about a week or ten days and when done and the Pipe covered I will forward you a Plan showing location and Profile of the pipe line.

I take this opportunity to say that I think Mr. Crowell appears to be most capable and reliable and is doing the work both efficiently and economically and is taking every care to ensure its being satisfactory in so far as the installation is concerned.
With reference to the agreement for the Right to cross the lands of Messrs. Snide.

I left copy of the agreement with the Rev. Father Mackie to be submitted to and discussed with the Snide Brothers but owing to their having been busy in connection with farm work I have only now been informed that the agreement is satisfactory and will be executed upon payment of the consideration, viz: $350.00

Will you forward this amt. to me or to Father Mackie, or remit direct to Messrs. Snide.

I would suggest that as the parties granting the concession on both elderly men it would be advisable to complete the matter with as little delay as possible.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

This agreement made and entered into this 24th day of July in the year 1929 between Daniel Snide and Alexander Snide of Shubenacadie in the County of Hants and Province of Nova Scotia, Farmers, and joint owners and occupants of the farm and lands commonly known as the Snide Farm, and hereinafter called Snide Brothers, of the one part, and the Department of Indian Affairs of the Government of the Dominion of Canada hereinafter called the Department of Indian Affairs of the other part,

Witnesseth:- that for and in consideration of the sum of fifty Dollars paid by the said Department of Indian Affairs to the said Snide Brothers, the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged, and other consideration hereinbefore referred to, the said Snide Brothers have agreed to and do hereby grant to the said Department of Indian Affairs the right and privilege of constructing and maintaining a pipe line, for the purpose of supplying water to the Indian College, across the lands of the said Snide Brothers from "Snide's Lake" so called, to the boundary of the said lands on and along the line of the present excavation for a width of five feet measured each direction from the center of the said Pipe line and to extend into or under the waters of the said Lake to such a distance as shall be considered necessary or required for the purpose of obtaining a suitable or sufficient supply of water.

Together with the right to the said Department of Indian Affairs their Servants, Agents, Tenants, or successors in title to enter upon and cross over the said lands for the purpose of constructing, repairing, maintaining or renewing or reopening the said Pipe line as may be required, and to re-open or reopen the said Pipe line and in connection therewith to make such further excavation or openings as may be required, upon and subject to the condition that all such openings or excavation shall be filled in as soon as reasonably possible and the damage if any done to Grain, Hay, or other crops on the said lands due to or as the result of such use of the said lands shall be paid for by the said Department of Indian Affairs, the amount to be as agreed upon between the said Snide Brothers and the said Department of Indian Affairs or their agents or representatives; and in the event of failure of the said parties to agree upon the amount of such damage, the decision shall be left to three Arbitrators one of whom shall be chosen by the said Snide Brothers, one by the said Department of Indian Affairs, and the third by the two first chosen and the decision so arrived at shall be final.

In witness whereof the parties to this agreement have hereunto their Hands and Seals set and affixed this day and year first above written.

Indian Residential School.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
November 15th, 1929.

Dear Sir:

After paying the wages of the men for the week ending Nov. 9th, the balance in the bank for the Barn and interior fittings is $362.87, sufficient for about two weeks, so at the end of that time will you please send more money.

The Barn should be finished in four weeks at the outside and then we hope to move a bit faster with the work in the school.

It has been well nigh impossible to get carpenters to come here, that accounts for the few we have.

Have been making inquiries about cows and I believe it is a hopeless proposition to buy any kind of a decent cow at a reasonable price. The prices in the locality are more extreme than they were a year ago. Could you purchase them through the Dept. of Agriculture and ship them down here?

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Residential School.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Dec. 2nd, 1929.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find time sheets for week ending Nov. 23rd, amounting to $269.80. The cheque for that amount usually would be issued on the following Tuesday, Nov. 26th. But at that time we only had a balance of $158.80. So I used my personal account in order to pay the men. I received your cheque for $500.00 this morning. After depositing the $500.00 and issuing a cheque for $269.80 the balance is as shown on the time sheet, viz. $388.00.

Enclosed also is freight bill for $1.16.

For the week ending Nov. 30th, the time sheets call for $234.60 which will be paid to the men tomorrow. A freight bill of $4.12 for material for clothes closets etc. will only leave a balance of $148.12, which will not be sufficient to pay the men for this week.

The end of this week will practically see the Barn finished, but there remains considerable work in the school. So will you please let me have some more money.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Mr. J.B. MacLean
Asst. Deputy Secretary

Re: Gravel Supplied to Indian School
at Shubenacadie, N.S.

Dear Sirs:

At the instance of Rev. Father MacKay, the Department of Highways of Nova Scotia, supplied seven carloads of crushed gravel, from their crushing plant at Debert, Colchester County. This gravel was used in connection with fixing up the road, leading to, and around the school.

Father MacKay promised that he would arrange through your Department to pay for these carloads.

We attach, hereto, bill, amounting to $18.85, covering our cost of the gravel at the plant, plus freight charges from Debert to Shubenacadie.

Kindly let us have your cheque at the earliest possible date, as we wish to include this amount in the accounts of our year. We would be very glad if you would have cheque reach us before the 15th instant.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find duplicate copies of invoices for gravel from the Dept. of Highways, N.S.

In the first place I beg to inform you that they bill for seven cars whereas nine car-loads were used. The first five car-loads were looked after by the Dept. of Highways as to unloading, spreading etc. Those five car-loads took them up near the school, and that was as far as they were prepared to go. The other four car-loads were looked after by us. The freight was prepaid, and for a time I had the freight receipts but the Dept. of Highways asked for them so I sent them on. I kept a copy and the four first mentioned on their list are the ones I looked after, the freight charges on them are correct.

From the appearance of things I think that the Dept. of Highways will take it upon themselves to look after the labor in connection with the unloading etc. for Mr. Black, Minister of Highways gave me to understand that the work on the road proper would be done on that basis.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Rhodes, Curry Limited, Contractors of this Town, who built the new school for the Indians at Shubenacadie, have consulted me in reference to an amount of $1,000 which is being withheld from them on account of an adverse report that has been filed with the Department by J. W. Crowell, the Inspector appointed, I presume, by the Government to inspect this particular work.

A perusal of the correspondence would indicate that the floors in the basement and some other parts of the building were not in the condition called for by the Specifications. At first I was inclined to believe there was some faulty construction but on going into the matter fully with the Contractors I find the complaint of Mr. Crowell is that the surface of these floors was not waxed. I quote from the Specifications as follows:

"Finish of Concrete Floors - All concrete floors in basement and bathrooms and toilets on all other floors shall be finished with a topping of color mix in accordance with the specifications of the Master Builders Company or approved equal. The floors when finished shall be absolutely dust proof and water proof and trowelled to a hard smooth surface. The floors shall be finished in red and to the thickness of ¼."
I respectfully call your attention to the fact that under the Master Builders Company if the floors constructed as set out in the above Specifications are to be waxed, that is to be so specified by the architect. No such specification is to be found, and if that is the only complaint of Mr. Crowell and it is not a part of the contract I do not see how the Department is justified in withholding the money.

This would be an extra in my opinion. If the Department wished the floors waxed it would cost in the vicinity of $1,200.

If there is any doubt about this contention I wish you would look into it and advise me as to the attitude of the Department.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

I need not tell you that he has been working right along and at the same time figuring out the plans you left with us, giving me the amount and the kind of material most suitable to the work. Of course there were times when I thought that the work was not going fast enough, but I honestly think that we can show value for the money expended. If you do not feel that you would like to have his time extended again then I suppose I can keep him on the pay-roll here. We really need a small combination ice and milk house, an implement shed, hen-house, and a place for pigs, and a root cellar as the one in the building is not at all satisfactory. I would like to have Crowell till those things are finished, although it looks queer to have a foreman for two men, but as was understood when you were here he is a working foreman.

Hoping that you will drop me a line soon and let me know what you think is the best solution.

With kind regards to yourself and Mrs. Orr.
