Re Indian College Water Supply.
Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith account covering services during the past summer in connection with location and inspection of water supply pipe, and pumping station for the Indian College at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

You will note that the inspections were not at regular intervals as it was found necessary under the conditions existing to time my visits according to the progress of the work and the state of the weather, which was unusually dry when the excavation was made thus rendering it possible to cut to perpendicular walls.

Before the pipe was in place heavy rains had fallen causing the banks of the cut to cave in and choking the outlet from the swamp and affecting the character of the bottom on which the pipe rests, and (possibly) the grade in places sufficiently to cause under strain in the joints.

I had intended furnishing you with a plan showing the location of the line as finally located and a profile, but as this will call for an additional three or four days work and you may not consider it necessary I have decided not to prepare either unless instructed to do so.

May I ask you to let me have a cheque for the amount of the account as soon as may be convenient and oblige me very much.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Indian Residential School.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
March 28th, 1930.

Dear Sir:

It is not safe for me to go to the kitchen today, a mad cook is not a pleasant animal. Rice pudding and apple pies in the oven for three hours and not cooked is to say the least a bit provoking.

The kitchen range is a McLary and I don't think the trouble is there. With the wind in a certain direction the stove has no draught. The only solution is to build the chimney five to ten feet higher. If you ever had trouble of this kind in your home you will realize that the sooner the difficulty is adjusted the better for all concerned. There has been complaints from that quarter for some time, today was the limit.

Will you please let me know if I may go ahead and have the work done.

Yours very truly,

Shubenacadie, N.S.
March 24th, 1970

Dear Sir:

Concerning the outbuildings which we think are needed:

Hen House

Enclosed faded plan, we would like to add ten feet in order that we might have space for feed-room.

Dairy

A dairy house to suit twenty-five cows, with accommodations for cleaning milk cans. Under the same roof we would have the ice house. From what they have at the other schools you will know better than I could tell you what is really required.

Implement Shed.

About eighty feet long by twenty-five feet, which would allow for work shop and blacksmith shop at one end. Where machinery which would not be used during the winter is stored, we would propose hinged doors, otherwise doors on rollers. A good deal of the lumber could be had from the old barn, which I think is to be torn down. As for the roof we would like high enough to give us space to store in winter the screens and in summer the double windows. We have not space to store these things in the school.
Root Cellar

Taking down the old farm house we thought that the cellar could be converted into a root-cellar without any great expense. A coating of cement on the inside of the stone wall and raising the foundation a foot or two above ground, a cement floor with a drain of tile pipe. The present drain has been blocked up for some time. A double roof with straw or shavings in between would we think give us something as near frost proof as anything we can think of.

Store house

We hope that the day is not far distant when we will buy our flour and feed by the carload. So we think that there should be a building about the size and form of a box-car built in order that we would have a place to store flour and feed.

As to the cost of these buildings frankly I don't know and with Crowell gone I have no one that I could ask with any confidence.

Pig house

Something for about twenty-five hogs, about fifty feet by twenty-five alley way down centre and pens on either side, also space at one end for a slaughter house. I should not mention the enclosed sketch but it is to try and give you an idea of about where we think the buildings should be placed.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

SHUBENACADIE, N.S.
May 5th, 1930.

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Feller.

Re:- Shubenacadie Residential School.

MAIN BUILDING:

Father Mackey reports that, with a driving rain storm, there is a considerable leakage of water on every floor on the front of the building. This damage the plaster on all the floors and seeps through to the basement. The sub-contractor on the roof (from Dartmouth, Halifax) examined the roof and it was decided that it was not the fault of the roof. Father Mackey further states that he has heard of similar complaints at other buildings throughout the Province where "blue-nose" brick was used.

BARN:

Father Mackey stated that practically all the barns in Nova Scotia have lightning rods. He wished this matter to be brought to your attention and, if the Department considers this equipment necessary on the barn at the Shubenacadie School, Father Mackey has secured a quotation from Ettinger Bros. of $126.40 for the complete installation.

PUMP AND PUMP HOUSE:

The pump is not working properly and Mr. McKenzie, who surveyed the place, intends to visit Shubenacadie about May 5th and give Father Mackey some information regarding it. Following Mr. McKenzie's visit, Father Mackey will write the Department and I considered that, on receipt of this letter, it might be advisable to write the makers of the pump, viz., Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., who might be able to give some expert advice regarding its operation. The local agent of the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. was unable to advise Father Mackey exactly what action to take to remedy the difficulty.

BASEMENT FLOOR IN MAIN BUILDING:

Father Mackey states that this floor still requires some attention. He further stated that he understood that a certain amount had been withheld from the contractor with a view to having this condition of the floor remedied. If so, the contractor has not yet taken any action.
Currie

Dept wishes to determine offers for new printing site. — Do you advise form lots to north present property for the flag site or can a better site be selected between these town lots railroad.

Dear Sir:

Practically for the past month I have been waiting for information from Mr. Mackenzie, Surveyor of lands, for the exact distance from the lake to the pump-house, and the rise from the lake to that point. If I had that information then I intended writing Fairbanks-Morse, giving them whatever other details I could give and asking for a solution why the bigger pump is not working as it should. Dear Mr. Orr:

I have visited the School Building at Shubenacadie. I took Mr. Dunne, our Superintendent along with me, and examined the floors thoroughly. I must say I was very much surprised that fault could be found with floors such as we put in that building.

Father MacKey pointed out the bad places - there was only one - about four feet square in the Girls Play Room and one about the same size in the Dining Room.

The steps have been worn some, mostly on account of the children's boots. I noticed in the Boys section of the building, even the steel nosings have been worn.

It is almost impossible to keep any kind of a concrete floor in shape without some treatment. I would advise you to authorize putting on two coats of Hippo oil. I do not know of anything better for floors. We would be willing to rub down the rough places with fine carborundum and would do anything in reason to assist, but must say in all the buildings I have been in for the last year or so, I have not seen a better concrete floor than what we have put in that building.

I do not think it fair to hold up $1000.00 of our money for a small item like that, and I trust you will see your way clear to authorize the payment of the balance due us. I assure you we would appreciate receiving this payment, very much.

Yours very truly

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find time sheets for the week ending August 22nd. Note that balance is $66.37.

As intimated in a previous letter I am not satisfied that the work has been going on as it should, especially for the last month. The foreman himself says that they will be through on the 28th inst. I had a note from Mr. Foster some time ago saying that he had recommended another foreman. Mr. Foster is the defeated candidate in this constituency.

The money I have on hand will pay for three days this week, and I propose to lay them off then and wait to see what will be the outcome of all the talk. I don't think that any other crowd of men could do any less than the present crew. I am disgusted with them.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the copy of the letter you sent me on August 20th, inst., I wish to point out that the suction pipe is not 2½ in. but five inches. In the five 90 degree elbows, the first one is in the lake, ten feet below water line, and the pipe from lake for a distance of fifty feet is lower than low water mark. After entering pump house the suction pipe is reduced to three inches, connection from the five inch pipe to the larger pump. Three inch is the size of the suction entrance to this pump. For the smaller pump reduction is to two and one-half inch, and the connection is from the five inch pipe and not from the three. So in all the suction line we have about two feet and a half of two and a half inch pipe. As you will readily understand the party who wrote this letter was misinformed.

We have discussed the suction conditions. We think there is only one real way to ascertain what the pump is doing in as far as the discharge is concerned, and that is to place a pressure gauge in the discharge line and determine accurately the pressure against which the pump is working. You must be sure to get a gauge that is correctly calibrated, as we find many of the gauges about the country are out 10 to 15 lbs. In fact it would be very useful information to put a vacuum gauge on the suction right next to the pipe and see what vacuum is being produced and also know what pressure the pipe is developing. I think that you will find that the pump is delivering against a pressure of least 10 lbs higher than the ultimate pressure in the tank. We assume that the statement that the pump delivers against 65 lbs means that the pressure in the tank is 65 lbs.

If you find that the pump is delivering immediately at its discharge, 75 lbs or more, it is possible that you are overloading the 5 H.P. motor. We can only guess at this point, until you get somebody to put gauges on this pipe and let us get some real information.

We note the Rev. Mackey states that the voltage is 220 when the motor is running. This looks like a guess. Does he get that from a voltmeter or does he only assume? The same is true with regard to cycles. We have never yet seen a current that was 100% perfect, as indicated by Mr. Mackey's replies Nos. 9 and 10.

Now in connection with Mr. Mackey's statement that the motor is too light for the pump, if you are only delivering against 65 lbs pressure at the top, the motor is not too light for the job. If you are delivering against higher pressures it is quite possible that it is too light, but until you have definitely established that you are delivering against pressures in excess of 65 lbs, we cannot say that the motor is overloaded. When the motor left here was in a first class condition, it may be that something has occurred which has disturbed its set-up arrangement. If you will make a minor test you can see whether or not the motor is in good order. If you have no voltmeter, and cannot get a volt reading, when the motor is running, you may be able to get an idea of whether or not the voltage is up to 220. If you disconnect the motor from the pipe and just run the motor light and see if it comes up to speed. If it does not come up to speed and running light, you know perfectly well that the voltage is not up and even with the current required to run the motor light. A motor should run at the full 1200 R.P.M. when light, if the voltage is up to 220. If the voltage is below 220 and the motor runs slow, even when running light, you can be sure that when the motor is working to 3/4 or full load, that the conditions will be infinitely worse.

Dear Sir:

On receipt of your letter of the 5th instant enclosing questionaire we forwarded same along to our Montreal office. We are this morning in receipt of the following letter from them regarding your pumping outfit.

"Your letter of the 5th, instant received, and we have read same, and also noted the answers to our questions that the Rev. Mr. MacKay has given us.

We note, in the first instance, that the 2½" suction line is 11½ ft. long, that it has five 30 deg. elbows, and that the static lift is 17 feet. The five elbows are equivalent to 25 feet of linear pipe, therefore, the length of the suction is equivalent to 1305 feet. With the pump running at capacity, namely 85 gallons per minute, the friction will be equivalent to 100 feet, and with the 17 feet static lift the total suction lift would be 115 feet. Now, this is an impossible condition, and the pump will never pump to full capacity. The 2½" suction line will not give more than 1200 to 1500 gallons per hour through the 11½ feet with 5 elbows and 17 feet static lift. That is to say, with the full vacuum that it is reasonable to expect, this is the maximum amount of water that it can be depended upon to discharge. This condition will cause a self-ailing typhoon pump to hammer badly.

We had exactly the same condition in the building next door to us with a 5000 gallon typhoon operated by a Fairbanks Morse 1½ H.P. motor operating against a pressure of 100 lbs. The pump hammered and banged and made such terrific noise that we had to do something. We tried two things, and found that both worked. We slowed the pump down so that it would pump only the capacity that the suction line would deliver under normal suction conditions. The pump worked smoothly. However, we did not have enough water, so we enlarged the suction pipe and speeded up the pump, and it worked perfectly.

Dear Sir:

On my way from Halifax, I called in to see Rev. J. P. Mackey of the Indian School at Shubenacadie. My work through the Provinces is visiting such Institutions as yours and checking over their Kitchen Equipment, etc., and I find that there are two items which I am sure will be both a time and financial saving to this Institution, namely, the Potato Peeler and Bread Slicer.

Ottawa, March 25, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the carpenter engineer at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. Occasionally, when a valued male employee at one of our institutions wished to marry, the Department has provided a separate cottage for him. At other times, space has been found in the main building for a young married couple who are without children. In other cases, a married employee has had to find quarters elsewhere than at the school. I regret, at the present time, that there are no funds for the purpose of erecting a cottage; but, if you can find space in the main building for Mr. MacLeod and his wife, there would be no objection. In this event, the wife should have sufficient duties at the school to pay for at least her board and room.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. T. H. McWilliam, Mgr.

Following are the pertinent facts of this matter:

Our 5000 gal. Typhoon Pump actually has a displacement of 5,364 gals. per hr.

The original chain drive, of which no record was kept, operated the pump at 285 r.p.m., the maximum being 215 according to factory rating. At a speed of 285, neglecting slip, and assuming a combined efficiency of 65% for the pump and the drive chain, 6-3/4 H.P. motor would be absorbed.

It was not possible to obtain sprocket with more than 114 teeth and such a sprocket was supplied after my visit. The pump was then not operating as slowly as I recommended, but is running at 191 R.P.M. requiring 6 H.P.

Considering that the maximum horsepower demand occurs only during the final two or three minutes in pumping up the tanks - they are hydro-pneumatic tanks - a 5 H.P. motor should not be seriously overloaded. That is to say the job ought to be O.K. now, particularly as the above H.P. calculations neglect slip of the pump.

Father MacKey's statement quoted by the Halifax Office to the effect that "it does not deliver as much water as the 2500 gallon unit" would indicate that either the suction line is partially obstructed or there is something wrong with the Pump. Unfortunately, there is no specific information as to the speed the pump is running, and the statement of Father MacKey, quoted above, is unlikely to be based on actual measurement of the water delivered.

It would be an expensive matter to install a 2500 gal. pump in place of the 5,000 gallon. If it is really necessary to still further reduce the capacity a Flex-Mor Drive, ratio 6.96:1 would give a speed of 165 R.P.M. Still, neglecting slip, 148 R.P.M. would require just 5 H.P. with an efficiency of 65% and with the tank at maximum pressure further assuming that the pump pressure exceed the tank pressure by 5%. The Flex-Mor drive would cost about $70.00 at Montreal.

I suspect that either the pump is not just right or the suction line is partially obstructed, so that only the capacity of the smaller pump, 2500 gallons per hour, can pass.

If I am going to be in Halifax during the next month or six weeks, or so, I believe the best way to take care of this would be to have you ship to me at Shubenacadie, or our Halifax Office, the following:

2 Chain Tongs for 5" & 6" pipe
2 Large Stillsons
1 Vacuum Gauge
1 Pressure Gauge of known accuracy
1 Breast Drill with drill to suit pressure gauge and vacuum gauge conn.
1 Tap for the same 1-speed indicator
This is not exactly a job for a plumber and our mechanics at Halifax are not equipped to handle the pipe. A vacuum gauge applied to both pumps in turn would tell a great deal about the condition of the suction. As the job now stands, and with the information we have, there is no apparent reason for the complaint that the pump is not delivering its capacity and that the motor is apparently overloaded - two contradicting conditions.

(sgd) S A KEP

Confirming the different conversations we have had in the last few weeks regarding the pumping station at the above school. I have looked over the recommendations that were made at the time and the different reports that were brought in by our own men, and sent in by the customer, and I cannot see what can be causing any trouble at the station besides the suction line.

The pump is a positive displacement pump and its capacity cannot be altered by anything but the change in its speed. Mr. Kemp reports the speed has been brought up to exactly what it should be. (I naturally assume that customer has opened the pump to check up if any of the valves or leather cups were in proper shape. It might happen that a suction valve would be broken, although this very seldom happens).

We have had on several occasions trouble with the suction line on some of our installations and have in some cases found that some of the metal used for galvanizing it partially clogged the pipe. In this case it is not probable that this metal would clog the pipe as it is too large, but it may have got under the flaps of the foot valve or check valve and may prevent it from opening properly. Again there may be some dirt getting in this pipe line, which also would prevent these valves from opening properly.

There is no reason that I know of why this 5,000 gallon pump should not pump its full capacity when pumping through 5" pipe as installed. I believe that if the customer would install a suction gauge on his line, he would know right away what is causing the trouble.

M. Gerin,

Dear Father Mackey:

I have your personal letter concerning Mr. Maxner's duties, and I feel that you have misunderstood the official communication, which I am returning. You will note that Mr. Maxner assumes no responsibility for the financial management or the general conduct of the school. In other words, you are responsible.

At Indian residential schools where the Department alone is financially responsible, it is the practice to have the principal prepare a quarterly fiscal statement, listing the receipts and expenditures. A local officer of the Department compares this list with the receipted accounts and paid cheques and certifies to its correctness. He also makes a general inspection of the school. Once every year or so, there will be a regular audit of the books of the school. This and Mr. Maxner's certificate on your financial statement will be necessary to your own satisfaction.

In the expenditure of public money, there are examinations and audits that may seem unnecessary to you at the present time, but which you will welcome as you become familiar with government regulations. Every payment I make is scrutinized by the Auditor General's Department and a receipt or other supporting paper is demanded.

Perhaps Mr. Maxner's visit has already cleared the air, for I hope he has a clear conception of his relations to you and to the school. You have the entire confidence of the Department, and you must not allow yourself to be disturbed by regulations that are associated with public business.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 5th ultimo, regarding the out buildings and improvements required at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, from the funds which are available, I am pleased to inform you that the Department will approve of you arranging for the erection of a pig house and a dairy of the dimensions as mentioned in your letter, also for the caulking around the windows and doors of the main school building, in order to overcome the damage which has occurred by rain penetrating and damaging the interior plaster on the walls.

You should make the purchase of the lumber and hardware required in the erection of the pig house and dairy building from the following:

Lumber ... Mr. O. J. O'Brien, Shubenacadie,
Hardware ... Mr. Watson Smith,

You may also engage the services of Mr. James Bell, of Shubenacadie, as foreman-carpenter, to oversee the work of the staff and boys in the construction of these buildings. The amount available for the work is $875, and all costs should be kept within this sum.

Regarding the repairs to the main school building, you may arrange with the Compressed Air Caulking Company, 5 Faulkner St., Truro, to carry out this work. This should consist of caulking around the windows and doors, also the tops and bottoms of stone sills, on the front of the building only, at the price quoted by them, viz., $125, which is to include materials and labour.

Please forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of lumber and materials purchased for the erection of the pig house and dairy building, also a certified account, in triplicate, for the services of the foreman-carpenter. The accounts should show in detail the number of days he was employed and the rate paid per day. You should also forward an account from the Compressed Air Caulking Company, which should show in detail the work performed, and this should also be certified by yourself.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have the work in the erection of the pig house and dairy building, and caulking of the front of the main building, carried out at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find the bills winding up the Hog-house and Dairy-ice-house, also pictures of them and the situation in relation to the barn and implement shed. We are sorry that the amount allowed for the work was exceeded by $29.37, but even at that I think we did fairly well. The total for outside help was $56.00 for a carpenter and $3.40 for an electrician.

The only equipment in the Hog-house costing any money is a Farmer boiler $20.00. In the Dairy we have a good three horse power upright boiler, a large sink for washing cans and milk pails, a hand basin for cleaning up before milking for the boys, a cream separator, and a small cooling room where the milk is kept.

We are very grateful to the Dept. for allowing us to put up these buildings, and with little exception giving us a free hand. I might say that this way of doing things gives us a lot less worry, and at the same time saves the Dept. considerable money. You will find no item for paint yet both buildings have had two coats. Twenty-one pigs in the hog-house, at the present time.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir:

I want to bring to your attention again the matter of a house for the carpenter-engineer. The farmer has a residence on the property, and the question of a house for the carpenter-engineer was spoken of just shortly after the School opened, three years ago. It has been mentioned every year since. The ability of the male help speaks for itself in that there has been no changes since the School opened.

I realize that in the interests of economy expenditure is curtailed, but at the same time I think that we could build the house at much lesser cost this year than at any other time. As in the building of the dairy-ice-house and hog-house, we could do a good share of the work ourselves. The plastering and electric wiring would be the only things requiring outside help.

The farmers house cost the Dept. four thousand dollars, I think we could build one of the same size for half that amount. We have not bothered you very much except for buildings, and I do hope that in this matter you will do the best you can for us. Please let me know if there is any possibility of having it done this coming summer.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Dear Mr. Phelan:

Many thanks for your letter of the 14th inst. In the meantime I have been scouting around trying to find the amount and cost of things. The amount of lumber exclusive for finnished floors and other inside work would come to 14000 ft. I can buy that here at $16. per thousand, amounting to $194.00. This O'Brion mentioned in the official letter of Sept; 14th, lives eighteen miles from here and would not land lumber here at that cost. He practically said last fall that he did not want any more business unless he could get his price of $20. per thousand. Hot air furnace would cost in the vicinity of $150.00.

If I were allowed I could buy the water and bath room fixtures in Halifax at much less cost than I can through Watson Smith. If it were not for his extra high charges we would have been within bounds for the dairy and hog-house.

The plastering and electric work would be about the only things requiring outside help. Please let me know what the next step is in order to get this house under way.

Cheque arrived and I am alright for another while, Thanks.

Sincerely,

There is a house on the school property which is now used by the farmer but another house is very necessary for the assistant farmer. The sum of $1,000 was included in our appropriation for the current fiscal year for necessary repairs at this school and I would recommend that Father Mackey be authorized to expend this amount in the erection of a house for the assistant farmer. A considerable amount of the work will be done by the staff and the padre himself and Father Mackey considers that the amount mentioned will enable him to build a suitable house. I may add that Mr. Mcleod, for whom the house is being built, not only assists on the farm but does all the minor repairs in connection with the heating plant and the plumbing. In this way, he saves the school a considerable expenditure each year and is a valuable member of the staff.

FUTURE REQUIREMENTS: (1) As pointed out above, the house for the assistant farmer is necessary at the present time and, as funds are available, I trust the Board will see fit to authorize Father Mackey to proceed in this matter.

(2) To complete the equipment in the laundry, a mangle is required, but there is no necessity for supplying this at the present time.

(3) There is still considerable seepage of water through the bricks on the south side of the building. Methods of improving this condition have previously been considered but, as yet, no satisfactory results have been obtained. Similar conditions exist in other buildings in Nova Scotia where the same kind of brick is used. When in Halifax I learned that the Imperial Oil Company had been having the same trouble with a large building that they had erected but had been successful in treating the bricks in such a manner as to prevent water seeping through. Father Mackey intends to see the Manager of this company with a view to ascertaining what they used and he will then write the Department.

(4) There is an ample supply of water from the lake and the water works system has been working very satisfactorily. The water is rather hard and it has been found that the steam and hot water pipes are corroding rather quickly. When the school was erected, the heating contractor stated that the pipes should last from ten to twelve years but pipes in the laundry had to be replaced within two years. I feel that this is a matter that should receive attention and I would suggest that the water be analysed with a view to determining what could be done to overcome the corrosion of the hot water pipes.

(5) No hens are kept at this school as there is no suitable building. At the present time, eggs can be purchased quite reasonably and there is no immediate necessity for the erection of a hen house. However, this could be kept in mind and, when funds are available, an appropriation of approximately $250 might be made for this purpose. A manure shed, with granolithic floor, might also be erected at some future date.
June 22, 1933.

Dear Father Mackey,

I spoke to the Deputy Minister yesterday with reference to the building of a house for the Assistant Farmer, and I think he is favorable to the project.

Will you kindly send me a rough sketch of what you propose building. You must keep in mind, however, that the cost of the building must not exceed $1,000.00. You might also let me know how you propose building this house, and what labour will be required, also the most convenient place to purchase the materials. When this information is received you will be further advised.

I note that you are having trouble with rain seeping through the brick work on the south side of the building, and that you are investigating other buildings having the same trouble. I will be glad to hear from you as to what is being done in similar cases to overcome this seepage.

Yours very truly,

H. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Rev. Father Mackey,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 22nd inst. I think the only house we could possibly build is one like the farmer occupies at the present time. That is 24ft. by 28, with the roof over the veranda. The one drive-way would be sufficient for both houses. The post would be 12ft. with upstairs windows built out from roof.

With the possible exception of outside help for plastering and electric wiring, the carp-eng. here and the boys will do the work. The amount allowed for the house will possibly not be sufficient to buy the material, for we do not want to put up a shack almost in front of the School. For that reason we figure on saving on the labor and using all available money on good material.

As for the convenient place for buying the necessary material, by all means the cheapest consistent with quality. Wm. Stairs, son & Morrow for all hardware, Spencer Bros. and Turner for windows, doors, flooring, and framing. Comment where the best price, same for roofing and side shingles, and for sand and gravel. Brick at Millers, tile from L.E. Shaw or N.S. Clay Works.

Hoping that we will have good news from you soon.

Kind regards to you and Mrs. Orr.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Nov. 29th, I beg to say, that during
the building of the hog-house and dairy-ice house about a year

who lives at Maitland, twenty miles from here. We followed those
instructions but Mr. O'Brien would only bring one load, as it did

We had from School property about seven thousand feet, milled

Dear Sir:

During one of the many cold spells, a small pipe which controls the cut-out for the pumps was frozen, with the result that the pressure of water went higher than usual. The pipe is not more than ten feet from a large hall burner, which was attended between five and six, the top of the hot water boiler was broken to pieces before seven thirty, P.M. For the past two years we have had considerable trouble with the heater and connecting pipes on account of the corrosion. During a visit by Mr. Thelat, we had repairs to make and showed him a three inch pipe which was so corroded that there was only about an inch space left for the water to pass through. We went into the question of using certain chemicals to remedy this condition but the cost was prohibitive.

We had to purchase a new hot water heater, and since all the pipe connections are three inch, it would be necessary to have all pipes threaded in Truro or Halifax, and run the risk of mistaken measurements etc. So in order to do the work ourselves we had to have dies, vice, pipe-cutters, and three foot wrench.

If I am not mistaken this is the first time we have asked the Dept. to pay a repair bill, but I think that this matter should be in the class of major repairs and not minor. Hoping that this will receive favourable consideration.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Lawrence Parker the assistant farmer occupies a rented house about two hundred yards from the School. The owner of the house wants to live in it on the first of May and has told Mr. Parker that he must vacate it by that time. As I have made known to you in previous letters, there is no house that could possibly be rented within a reasonable distance of the School, i.e., from one to two miles. The duties of the assistant farmer calls for him to be at the barn for morning milking not later than five fifteen. To do that I think you will admit that he should live near the School.

I realize that last year you built a house for the carpenter-engineer, and that we are asking a lot to have another built this year. But if you can possibly do it I earnestly hope you will, as then the housing problem for the male help, who are all married men will be settled for all time.

Hoping that you will give this matter your favourable consideration, and that we will hear from you soon.

Yours very truly,

Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Jan. 27th, 1926.

No. 51-0-5

Dear Sir:

On account of building the house for the assistant farmer last summer it was impossible to attend to some repairs in the School. I refer especially to the boys recreation, wash and bath rooms. The walls to within six inches of the floor are the ordinary plaster, and it has been impossible for us to keep them looking half decent. The plaster in many places is broken and even the cork board back of the plaster has been torn away. The only solution I can see is to take the plaster and cork board out and replace them by rough faced brick.

Last year we were informed that there was an amount of $300. for repairs. As it was not used for that purpose I wonder if it would be available for this year. The brick would cost about thirty-five dollars a thousand and I would judge that we would need about six thousand. There would be no extra labor.

Will you please let us know if we may figure on doing these repairs in the late spring or early summer.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Ottawa, February 3, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the boys' recreation room, wash room and bath rooms at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School and requesting that authority be granted for an expenditure of $300 in supplying the material required to carry out the repairs.

In this connection it is noted you recommend that the plaster and cork board be removed and replaced by rough faced brick. If brick were installed, would you not consider that, owing to the rough surface, it would be dangerous to the pupils in their play? In any event, the department will have no funds during the balance of the present fiscal year to authorize the purchase of the brick or other material for the purpose.

You might again draw this matter to the attention of the department about the end of April, next, at which time we will be aware what funds, if any, will be available for carrying out the repairs at your school. While our Estimates for the current fiscal year contained an item of $300 for the residence, only, to erect the residence for the Indian farmer, I would point out that, as the cost of the residence was over $1,400, all funds provided for your school year have been utilized.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Shubenacadie, N. S.
"I beg to submit the following report on my visit to the Shubenacadie Indian School:

Rooms.

Classrooms, dining rooms, kitchen, dormitories, locker rooms, lockers, wash rooms, recreation rooms, halls, storage rooms, etc., etc., all scrupulously clean and orderly with the exception of the walls of the boys' recreation room and the walls of the rooms on the south and east side of the building which through no fault of the school officials are I might say a disgrace in a building of this kind and certainly not a good example of the white man's standard of living to keep before the eyes of those Indian children.

Boys' Recreation Room.

In this room the plaster extends to the floor. Consequently is all broken to a height of some four feet. To repair those walls with plaster would only be a waste of money. The plaster should be replaced with tile or brick work to a height of at least four and a half or five feet from the floor. When this work is being done provision should be made to allow the firm attachment of a clothes' rail on the wall.

Walls of Rooms & Building.

Apparently the brick used in this building permits the passage of water through them. Indications of this can be seen on all walls of the building but as the prevailing wind and rain storms are from the south and east it is on the south and east walls that the effect is most apparent. On the inside walls the plaster is either badly stained, off, or falling off in many places in every room and while not an expert, am satisfied can see signs of deterioration in the walls from the outside. As this condition has existed ever since the building was erected, it is in my opinion that unless immediate steps are taken either by paint or some other method that will prevent this seepage of water, irreparable damage will be done the building and a heavy expenditure incurred in the near future."
Ottawa, April 2nd, 1936.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Dr. Thos. Robertson's report with reference to his visit to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, in which he refers to the condition of the walls of the boys' recreation room and, also, the walls of the rooms in the south and east side of the school. I may say that he distinctly points out that this condition is not due to any laxity on the part of the school officials.

In the current year's appropriation, there has been provided the sum of $400 for repairs and improvements at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. Please let me have your report, stating in what manner you consider this amount should be spent. You should give an estimate of the cost of the material and the cost of the labour for the work which you recommend. As soon as your report is received, the Department will give it immediate consideration. It should be definitely understood, however, that no work must be done until you receive explicit instructions from the Department.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir

I beg to report that on March 18th I arrived in Truro called on Mr. Fox, Indian Agent and with him visited the Reserve and school at that point.

We visited a great many of the Indian homes and I must say was very favorably impressed by the cleanliness and general activities in the homes.

While there are quite a number of old people as well as sick who are unable to support themselves on this reserve, among those who are able there seems to be a strong desire to support themselves and while I was there all were busy. That in the past white men have been engaged to build roads and do repairs on the reserve, is resented by the Indians and in my opinion justly so. There is no excuse for it; it only antagonizes the Indian and increases the cost of relief.

If there is no regulations making it obligatory for Agents to engage Indians (whenever possible) for all work on reserves, I believe there should be and that the regulation should be strictly enforced.

On our visit to the school we found fourteen pupils present out of an enrolment of 50. Several were at home sick with colds. The Teacher reported regular attendance.

The children appeared clean, attentive and fairly well nourished. The school room was in my opinion not so clean or neat as it should be, neither was the teacher so neat and tidy in her appearance. I drew this to the Agent's attention.
attention and he agreed to speak to her.

Mr. Fox has had previous experience in social work, I understand. He has made a good start here, he wishes to help the Indian but realizes and also tells them they must help themselves. I shall be much disappointed if Fox does not make a big improvement at Truro.

Would advise keeping an eye on this now as a suitable person as a full time Agent should such appointment be made.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) Thos. Robertson

Re grocery supplies. In my opinion these prices should be cut at least 10%. Talked with the Agent, he agreed. Think a letter from Dept. to him drawing his attention to necessity of securing better prices might assist him getting it adjusted.

Growell of Windsor N.S. The contractors, at the time placed the blame on the sub-contractors who did the roofing. In company with the inspector I made the trip between the ceiling of the top floor and the roof to the front of the building about an hour after this heavy driving rain storm had started. There are other buildings in the province which have the same trouble and I have talked the matter over with the superintendents of these buildings. Memorandum:

Doctor McGill,

I beg to report that on Wednesday of last week I made an inspection of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. This building was erected in 1929 and reports have been received by the Department during the last year or so that the building was being damaged during periods of heavy rain.

The survey of the interior of the building showed clearly that rain was penetrating the south wall of the building and doing considerable damage to the plaster and interior finish. The prevailing winds are from the south-east and it appears that the south wall is the only one that is noticeably affected.

I might say that when this school was erected the interior of all the exterior walls was water-proofed with a composition of tar and asphalt. This was applied direct to the hollow building tiles which were used in connection with the face brick in the construction of the outside walls. The face brick used in the building is extremely hard and it is practically impossible for water to penetrate same. The examination shows, however, that in spite of these precautions the rain is being forced through the wall during a driving rain from the south-east.

With a view to determining the best way of remedying the existing condition I inspected several of the large buildings recently erected in Halifax and in all cases I found that they are experiencing the same trouble. The Nova Scotia Hotel, erected a few years ago by the Canadian National Railway, spent about two years endeavouring to eliminate the trouble on their south wall. The results were all unsatisfactory until the entire outside surface of the wall was waterproofed by the Western Waterproofing Company, who have a
patented process for this class of work.

The Bell Telephone Co., the Capital Theatre, the Nova Scotia Light, Heat and Power Co., Bank of Montreal, Moir's Factory and other large buildings in Halifax have been waterproofed by the Western Waterproofing Company and the results have been entirely satisfactory, eliminating in all cases the penetration of rain through the walls.

It is extremely important that immediate attention be given to the waterproofing of the Shubenacadie School in order to safeguard the building, and I would recommend that arrangements be made immediately with the Western Waterproofing Co. to carry out this work. They guarantee their work for five years and have been strongly recommended to me by those who have employed them for this work.

The estimated cost is $2,000 and I have been advised that funds are available in the Vote for Indian Education to cover the cost.

Attached to my memorandum are five photos taken at the Shubenacadie School:

No 1. - A general view of the front of the building, which is the southern exposure and the wall requiring waterproofing.

No 2. - A detail of the front entrance.

Nos 3 and 4. - Interior details of one of the classrooms on the south wall showing the damage to the plaster around the windows.

No 5. - A view taken from the steps of the School which shows the three bungalows built and occupied by male members of the staff of the school.

FIRE BROKE OUT ELEVEN FORTY FIVE AM IN BOILER ROOM DAMAGE TO FLOOR AND WALLS IN CHAPEL REPORT TO FOLLOW

REV J P MACKEY..
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
November 20th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following concerning the fire which we had here on November 19, 1936.

About 11:45 A.M., a Sister came to my room, at the time I was in the bath-room, and shouted to me that there was a fire in the boiler room. Within a very short time I was in the boiler room, the place was full of smoke, and I could see flames behind the boiler near the outside wall. I got the hose off the rack and ran with it to the garage to get away from the smoke. By that time, Father Brown, Stewart Cooper and some of the bigger boys were there. Asking them to get the water turned on, I left to come up to the office, telephoned to the Central Office and asked her to get us what help she could. I went back to the boiler room but they could not get water through the hose. We found out afterwards that any sharp bend in the hose would prevent the water from coming through. Seeing that we were not getting anywhere with that hose, I came back to the first floor and put the hose from that rack out the window in order to get at the fire, which was greatest in the corner made by the Chapel wall and roof of the coal bin. In the meantime, McLeod had gone to the pump house, started the second pump, and stepped up the pressure. We got very little water from the hose on the first floor - no pressure. (Found out afterwards that the bushing that the valve stem turns through was cracked and would allow stem to turn without opening plunger.

While this was going on, a great crowd had arrived from the village, including the two members of the R.C.M.P., and all the buckets in the house and other utensils were used. It was not very long before the fire in the boiler room was just smoldering. But the fire had made its way up alongside the small crack between the sheet metal covering of the boiler room, at a point where the sheet metal meets the I beam, and worked its way along the I beam into the two-by-six which rest on edge on the I beam. The only way we could get at it was from above, on account of the sheet metal being nailed to the two-by-six, and this necessitated cutting into the floor of the Chapel. By one o'clock it was a matter of locating those places between floors which were slowly burning.

The fire wood was put in the boiler room sometime during the month of June, when there was no fire in the boiler, and there is no doubt but that what was left of it, should have been removed when the
fire was started in the boiler. Nevertheless, there has been wood in
the same place year after year and no fire. There are some things
which lead me to believe that the fire was not started from any spark
from the boilers. It has always been a problem to prevent boys from
making their way to the boiler room, in order to have a smoke, and it
has happened that whatever they should be smoking, would be thrown
away, should anyone come along.

As far as we can find out at this time, Gilbert Francis was told
to shake up the fire about ten forty-five. At eleven o'clock, Ed
McLeod, carpenter-engineer, went to the entrance of the boiler room
to get the boy, but he was not there and he did not notice any fire at
the time. Gilbert Francis was the only boy who was supposed to be in
the boiler room that morning. There were a few boys at the barn, but
as yet I have not had time to check up on them.

Before closing I wish to express my sincere thanks to the men of
Shubenacadie for the ready response and for their strenuous efforts
to help us out of a most serious situation.

Yours truly,

CHIEF CAUSES

AND THE REMEDY

RESTO-CRETE

Resto-Crete System Patented in Canada and United States
The main cause of the disintegration of concrete and masonry is water penetration, which washes out the salts from the masonry and causes fracture from frost action, and corrosive action from the acids in the air. Also, in the case of reinforced concrete structures, the water corrodes the reinforcing steel resulting in swelling of the steel and consequent fracture.

18% to 20% of a brick wall surface consists of joints

It follows then that faulty workmanship, shrinkage and disintegration of mortar cause about 75% of all cases of leaky walls, and it is no wonder when as much as 20% of the surface is subject to mortar shrinkage and disintegration.

Rain finds easy entrance, for even during a gentle shower there is a measurable film of water constantly flowing over an exposed wall. But when driven by a strong wind, the flow of water into the cracks is almost as if the water flowed over a horizontal surface.

In dry cold weather the heat loss through the openings in brick joints is a very serious factor. In wet weather the walls lose a large part of their insulating value.

THE PURPOSE OF RESTO-CRETE

It is the purpose of Resto-Crete Material and Service to make walls a "uniformly dense face of masonry," impervious to the entrance of moisture, but permitting of wall "breathing," mentioned later.

If the material of the defective masonry wall is dense and highly resistant against moisture, then a treatment of the joints only will be necessary.

If the bricks, stone or other material are soft, porous and show noticeable signs of flaking, checking, or other evidence of water penetration and disruption by freezing or other disintegration, then an overall treatment is advisable.

All concrete and masonry structures show some disintegration in the course of years. This may be very slow for a great many years, then suddenly accelerate. The location of the cause of disintegration and determination of the cure is the work of a specially trained organization.

Thorough examination is of first and vital importance.

WHAT WE DEMANDED OF RESTO-CRETE

Any material and method of restoring disintegrated masonry, to be efficient, must conform to the specifications, laid down more than 75 years ago by a group of scientists, for the requirements of waterproofing materials:

1. The material must penetrate easily into the masonry surface and remain there on drying.

2. The material must not concentrate on the surface so as to form a hard crust, but at the same time it must harden the surface sufficiently to resist erosion. (It must densify the surface by filling the holes and must subsequently become hard).

3. The material must prevent the penetration of moisture, and at the same time allow moisture to escape. This is possible because water as liquid will not penetrate where as vapor it will escape. Furthermore it is possible for a wall to absorb a proper amount of moisture without admitting seepage. This "breathing" of a wall is necessary to prevent disintegration or rotting of the material internally. This is probably the most important consideration of a waterproofing.

4. The material must not discolor or in any way alter the original appearance of the surface.

5. The material must expand and contract uniformly with the surrounding surface so as not to cause flaking.

6. The material must be non-corrosive and harmless in use.

7. The material should retain its preservation effect indefinitely.

Resto-Crete Embraces ALL the Requirements of a Satisfactory Job

When the foregoing specifications for waterproofing materials were laid down, the scientists went beyond the available materials of their day. Some materials accomplished a part of the specifications but none accomplished ALL of them. It was only by making a long study of the merits and demerits of various materials that a compound of materials was discovered that fulfilled ALL the specifications.

RESTO-CRETE MATERIAL
Resto-Crete Material is guaranteed to accomplish ALL the requirements of a satisfactory job.

Resto-Crete Material penetrates without concentrating on the surface. It is impervious to seepage but sufficiently receptive to permit the required ingress of air and egress of vapors to insure proper wall breathing. It not only will not discolor a wall, but it perfectly identifies itself with the material of the wall in color and texture, and adds density and permanence. Services

All work is done exclusively under contract and guaranteed to be and remain watertight. We sell no materials. Each office has a corps of trained mechanics working under the supervision of an engineer.

Contracts are taken for Treating Structures of Concrete, Brick or other Masonry, either old or new. Architects or engineers are invited to call our Waterproofing Engineers in for consultation to assist them in the solution of problems involving Waterproofing, Damp-proofing, Oilproofing, Restoring Disintegrated Concrete, etc.

Method Used

This system involves the use of Ironite Waterproofing, which is a finely pulverized gray iron containing chemicals. Upon brushing this on the walls with the addition of water, the particles are lodged in the surface pores. Due to the chemicals, rapid oxidation of the iron takes place with the resultant expansion of the iron particles. This swelling completely fills the surface pores and seals them against leakage. Sufficient coatings are applied to thoroughly fill all pores. The early coats make a filling or stuffing for the surface pores, and the succeeding coats form a highly oxidized iron filament. This iron oxide surface is extremely dense and impervious, not alone to the action of water, but also to oils, dilute acids, etc.

The treatment is applied on either the pressure side or the side opposite. In the latter case it is impossible to force the waterproofing away from the wall as the particles inside the surface pores have expanded therein and are an integral part of the structure.

Advantages of This Method

Our system is a positive one, requiring no assistance from integral compounds in the concrete. The bond secured between the waterproofing and the structure is so perfect that it will resist any hydrostatic pressure the structure is capable of withstanding. See comparison shown on front page and note the large saving in construction cost.

Lead Expansion Bolts for Montreal Dock Repairs

Lead expansion bolts have been used in an interesting new way by The Western Waterproofing Co., Montreal, Canada, on work just completed for the Harbor Commissioners of Montreal. The harbor dock walls of the Bickerdike Pier had become badly cracked and broken up through years of wear and tear of shipping and action of the elements. It was decided to repair the dock by completely resurfacing with Gunite and in this operation "Cinch" Expansion Bolt-Anchors played an important part.

All soft, loose and defective concrete was first cleared from the wall faces, cutting away with pneumatic hammers and wire-brushing. A clean, solid, toothed concrete surface resulted, to form a sound base for a solid bond with the Gunite. The amount of defective material removed varied, 2 in. being the minimum. The roughened surface was then given a coating of powdered cast iron mixed with water and an oxidizing agent to prevent the rusting of wire mesh and anchor-bolts by the penetration of dampness or water from the upper dock surfaces, and to bond the Gunite to the structure.

Holes 2 in. deep and ½ in. in diameter were then drilled in the surface 20 in. apart and staggered. A ¼ in. wire nail, secured by calking in two separate ¼ in. plain unit "Cinch" Expansion Bolt-Anchors (described in detail in LEAD, January, 1933), made and supplied by Canadian "Cinch" Anchoring Systems Limited, Montreal, was inserted in each hole with the nail ends projecting about 3 in. Steel mesh having 2 in. square mesh made of No. 10 gauge wire was placed over the nail ends which were then bent up and over, securing the mesh firmly to the wall. Gunite was then sprayed on and before setting hard was smoothed off and corners rounded, completing a highly satisfactory and permanent repair job.

As can be seen from the sketch, lead expansion bolt-anchors utilize the principle of expanding one or more lead alloy cone rings within a hole by calking them over iron cones placed base down on the head of a bolt. The anchorage is also used to anchor the threaded end of the bolt in the hole by using the iron cone tapped with a standard machine bolt thread of any size. They are used for all types of anchorages in concrete and masonry, for installing machinery, motors, shafting, pipe lines, theatre seats, and for electrical, plumbing, heating and ventilating work.

At first glance the two pictures above would hardly seem to show the same building, the one having the appearance of a typical concrete structure, the other suggesting the grace of a beautiful stone building. Yet they are the same; the structure being the new addition to the Associated Screen News Building, Montreal, Quebec. The Architects were J. W. Orrock and N. B. Reardon of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, and the contractors were the A. Janin Construction Company. The office in the foreground is of monolithic concrete, and was subsequently treated with a light colored RESTO-CRETE.

Monolithic construction is relatively inexpensive; further, it is admirably suited to the modern tendency in design. However, in the past, the great difficulty has been that concrete surfaces are soon pitted and corners broken off if left exposed to the weather, even when carbonated rubbed. The disintegration is due to the penetration of water, and the subsequent freezing and leaching out of necessary strength-giving constituents of the cement. Add to this the proven impossibility of preventing the ingress of water by painting the concrete with oil and cement paints, or with the so-called "liquid waterproofings", and you have one big reason why monolithic concrete has lost some favor in the past few years.

The Resto-Crete System has superseded these makeshift treatments. By its use it is now possible to insure a permanently beautiful and hard finish, for it has been distinctly designed to permit the wall to breathe and at the same time prevent the ingress of water. This is done essentially by filling the open pores with a non-capillary, yet slightly porous, hard cement material. The method is patented and applied only by Western Waterproofing Company licensees.

An even more striking example of monolithic concrete construction, with the RESTO-CRETE after treatment, is the new Court House built at Alpena, Michigan, last year. Prior to the Resto-Crete application, an Ironite bonded slush coat was applied to true up corner lines and fill surface holes. This is in contrast to the Montreal building on which the characteristic board marks were retained.

From such signs as these we are lead to prophecy renewed activity for monolithic concrete.

NO, THIS BUILDING did not go through an earthquake! It wasn't even improperly built or designed, according to our modern view, and no settling occurred. The condition is only an exaggerated case of what Mother Nature is doing to all buildings, starting at the time of building and continuing until the wrecker comes to haul them away, as our experience with thousands of similar failures proves.

How long is your brick building going to last? Probably not as long as you anticipate unless you originally figured its depreciation at five per cent per year. For not only is it going to be preyed upon by such elemental forces as the freezing and thawing of accumulated water, and the actual dissolving out of necessary components of the masonry by water, and by atmospheric acids from cool soot but the view now commonly held is that it will crumble to pieces by unequal expansion of mortar and brick units. The building shown above has clearly demonstrated the effects of volume expansion.

Volume expansion, as here referred to, means the actual increase in dimensions of mortar and brick from their taking up water, rather than from temperature variation. For instance, it has been shown that a rich Portland cement mortar will expand as much under a rain of a few hours' duration as it will under a temperature change of 100 degrees Fahrenheit!

Since brick won't expand this much, a shearing force results between brick and mortar, and something must give way. The result of the above treatment was that the wall held and the brick broke in places. If a weaker mortar had been used, a poorer bond would have resulted and the mor-

tar would have crumbled. But, in any event, the degree of this volume expansion would have increased during the years with the continued inflow of water.

But, you may ask, what of the numerous brick buildings built a century or two ago which are still in good condition?

Here, we answer that they were built with a mortar which did not permit the actual flow of water through the joint. They were fat mortars. As soon as their capillarity was satisfied, no more water penetrated. Again, the old lime mortars have gradually hardened by a natural chemical process which has made them more impermeable.

Our ancestors knew materials by long years of working experience with them. Today, we all are suffering from the misuse of many valuable new materials.

What is more, the treatment is preventing ninety-nine per cent of the water that would normally enter from doing so, the other one per cent being atmospheric moisture which must be allowed to enter and leave at will for the good of the building. The masonry in this building is not going to expand further, because the protective treatment is noncapillary toward water.

Years of continuous research and practice have proved to us that the Resto-Crete treatment is the answer to the perplexing disintegration problems of today. Applied to a building when first built, it will prevent the development of conditions like the above.

FOURTEEN THOUSAND pounds per square inch! No wonder concrete spalls when this great force is liberated within it by the rusting of reinforcing bars. Concrete is good for only a few hundred pounds in tension. Since steel expands in volume by at least two hundred per cent when it rusts, a tension is produced greater than concrete can withstand.

This is what happened to the concrete column shown at the left. Moreover, it happens to a greater or less degree to all reinforced concrete structures. Most concrete structures over a few years old show some spalling on the surface, and at least ninety percent of these marks of disintegration are due to the rusting of the embedded steel.

Steel rusts only because a combination of water and carbon dioxide from the air comes into contact with it; and these agencies can reach the imbedded steel only by passing directly through the concrete.

In other words, the disintegration of concrete from the rusting of reinforcing steel is merely another indication of the greatest need for adequately weatherproofing all masonry surfaces. We often fail to recognize this need because the extent of the damage does not appear on the surface until the condition becomes acute. As an example, the only visible indication of the serious condition of the column at the left was a few surface cracks.

We wish you could look through our microscope in the laboratory and watch the disintegrating forces of nature at work. You would see a drop of water placed on a masonry surface rapidly work its way through fine capillary tubes into the densest concrete. You would see water causing steel to rust; and would be amazed as you saw the fine rust tentacles pushing out from the main body, filling every crevice, and finally breaking the weaker structure and pushing it out of the way. You would see water dissolving out some of the softer structures. Or, again, you would see a water solution of the common atmospheric acid gas (sulphuric acid) rapidly eating up even the strongest crystal structures. We know that even the most nontechnical observer of these sights would conclude:

1. That the presence of water in the masonry is essential to the operation of these disintegration processes.
2. That the deep penetration of water, whether rain or dew, depends upon the capillarity of the surface through which it may enter.
3. That the successful weatherproofing of a masonry surface requires the balancing of many more forces than are usually considered.

We have discussed in other places the important disintegrating effect of volume expansion of concrete materials as they take up water,* and also the necessity for preserving an evaporating surface on the exterior of all masonry structures.** Many other forces are involved at different times. In fact, there is no single procedure that will work successfully in treating every structure of concrete or of stone or of brick.

Particularly is it true that a job is dependent upon spall and breakage allowances for special handling. It is essential in such a case that a trained engineer be on hand, for steel that is badly rusted must be replaced, the concrete surface must be properly prepared to secure a strong bond between old and new concrete, and strong concrete must be placed. A good job of patching not only gives a good appearance but also restores the original balance of stresses and strains between concrete and steel.

HOW PERMANENT IS LIMESTONE?

How would you like to stand under a shower bath of sulphuric acid for your whole life? Sounds silly, doesn't it? Yet your building, and every other structure, road, and sidewalk, literally lives just this life.

For chemical analysis of the air in New York City alone has shown that approximately 1,000 tons of sulphuric acid gas is discharged into the air every twenty-four hours from the combustion of coal. This gas, in combination with the water vapor in the air, forms sulphuric acid, which in turn is deposited along with soot and other dirt on every square inch of exposed masonry.

Even non-ceramic building material—limestone in particular—is readily attacked by sulphuric acid. The result of this attack is quite obvious on buildings located in cities having high smoke densities as compared with those having low smoke densities. A striking example is to be observed in the case of old cast-iron objects of limestone, which endured for ages in their native climate, but when subjected to a few years' exposure in our city squares showed an amazingly accelerated rate of disintegration.

Sulphuric acid disintegration, like other types of disintegration in masonry, is due mainly to the penetration of water; for rain water contains acid in, then below the dissolved salts of the acid backs out and slowly washes them away. As a result the masonry becomes progressively more porous and capillary to water. Then, under proper conditions, ice crystals and crystals from dissolved salts form in the exterior surface layers and the familiar exfoliation or spalling of the surface occurs.

Besides disintegration specifically due to sulphuric acid, a greater destructive agency is the continued inflow and outflow of water—from any source; for water itself, in large quantities, is capable of dissolving out important constituents of limestone. Fortunately, however, in the case of limestone, nature has provided a natural water balance: if not over-exposed to water and sulphuric acid it will gradually build up a hard, dense surface layer which becomes increasingly resistant to natural disintegrating forces. Such surfaces can be found in well-protected areas on most limestone buildings. In fact, there are many complete limestone buildings in existence today which show no disintegration whatever.

A better picture of this may be gained from the right half of Fig. 1. This section of the magnified limestone surface shows the dense, hard particles of "limestone sandstone" enclosed by a network of parallel pores forming a porous, sponge-like mass. In newly quarried limestone most of these pores are filled with a loosely packed lime material, which is the basic material employed by nature in building up a resistant surface. This material, if unchanged by nature (as is the case behind the surface layers), is the most easily attacked and, consequently, disintegrated acid.

Now if anyone is used for cleaning, this protective surface is removed and many years may be required to restore it. The disintegration occurring in the meantime alone is enough to condemn it.

Since we cannot control our buildings under the most adverse weathering conditions, we are faced with these facts: (1) Acids in the air and water dissolve out valuable salts from the limestone; (2) Alternate wetting and drying causes volume changes in the individual stones, which tend to break down the mortar bed, thus permitting the entrance of water and acids. Therefore, to preserve our buildings, we must apply the fundamental principles of weatherproofing by synthetically building a dense, hard, non-capillary surface, which retains breathing ability, inertness and strength.*

In the left-hand half of Fig. 1, and in Fig. 2, these principles are clearly illustrated. Note that the surface characteristics are in no way altered, but that the open pores are completely filled. No wax or paraffin has been applied to melt and collect dust, or to prevent breathing. No oil or glaze has been creosoted to prevent surface spalling by the formation of interior salt crystals. The surface performs in accordance with Natural Laws, at the same time giving protection against the ravages of water and sulphuric acid.

These characteristics make the Resto-Crete System the only one of its kind in the field for the protection and decoration of limestone.

HOW MUCH MONEY has the above specification cost owners without their having received one penny's worth of permanent protection for their buildings?

Granted that the material and workmanship that go into a good tuck-pointing job are the best (they are still no better than the original materials), and that apparently all of the work required is done, what permanent good has been accomplished?

From our knowledge of buildings and their life-expectancy, we are not safe in assuming that the depreciation of exterior wall surfaces is at least three per cent. per year. This deprecation usually takes place in the mortar material, rather than in the masonry units, and it does not mean that on a building five years old fifteen per cent. of the mortar has fallen out. It does mean, however, that the alternate wetting and drying of the wall surfaces, with the carrying into the walls of acids from the air, cause soluble parts of the mortar to be dissolved out and washed away at an alarming rate. Thus, it is left very much depleted in strength and much more porous than it was originally.

In a tuck-pointing job, only the holes where mortar has fallen out, or is loose, are repaired. The extent of the repairs is left to the good judgment of the man on the scaffold. If defective mortar were not repaired, excellent judgment is used and all visible defects are repaired, the only advantage gained is that depreciation of the repaired parts must start from the beginning again, while unrepaired parts will continue to cause trouble and will require periodic repair. It would seem, therefore, that to say "—and tuck-point where necessary" means the beginning of a more or less continuous repair job.

The cost of a tuck-pointing job is mostly labor, because of the small amount of inexpensive materials used. Tuck-pointing requires only the examination of all surfaces; therefore, to tuck-point repeatedly a part of the joints in a surface adds very materially to the cost of maintenance over a long period. Would it not be better to make all joints and surfaces permanently impervious to moisture under operation, even though the first cost were slightly higher?

In previous issues of the RESTO-CRETER and in Technical Bulletin No. 3-A, we have discussed the fundamentals of weatherproofing, stressed the use of a non-capillary material, and have cited typical jobs. These ideas are sound unless they are read with understanding and so acted upon.

Let us suppose you are going to have your building repaired. Are you going to write a specification for the work accomplished which leaves the determination of what you want done to the judgment of the laborer on the scaffold in permitting him to "—tuck-point where necessary?" Or are you going to be sure that the money you spend will accomplish something? Through can do by providing that every square inch of the entire external surface of your building is weatherproofed according to the fundamental laws for such work; that it is guaranteed to stay weatherproofed; and that the work is to be done by an organization with enough understanding of your problem to insure you an intelligently executed job.

THOSE who know most about concrete are insistent on the fact that, when made properly, it is perfectly waterproof, and therefore water-proof. The difficulty in practice is to get the concrete made well enough to be waterproof. There has been a great improvement in the quality of most concrete work during recent years, particularly since the importance of the subject was more generally known. But really good cement is still so much the exception that a great many concrete surfaces still require to be waterproofed.

When concrete is not waterproof the reason generally is that there are voids throughout that make it porous. The obvious way of curing this condition is to fill these voids with cement. It is found, however, that cement alone does not fill the voids perfectly, so many other substances have been tried out. Substances such as oil paint and tar have been used unsuccessfully.

One of the most satisfactory waterproofing materials so far established in use is iron oxide, which has been employed for about 30 years in foundations and other structures beneath the ground level. It is brushed on the concrete as finely ground cast-iron powder. This oxidizes rapidly and thereby swells, filling the pores of the concrete completely. In some cases a thin protective coating of cement is put over the iron. This is called the "Ironite" process of waterproofing concrete.

The dark colour of the "Ironite" waterproofing obviously makes it of little use above the ground level where appearance is an important factor. A prolonged search for a more suitable material that would give a similarly satisfactory result in filling the pores of the concrete was rewarded about five years ago with the discovery of the mixture now known as "Resto-Crete." Portland cement comprises the larger part of the mixture, since cement itself is obviously the best material to use, provided all the requirements are met. To the cement is added a small amount of material to make the concrete water-resistant, sufficient finely ground iron oxide to ensure oxidation that will fill all the voids, and a small proportion of inert material that makes the surface appreciably more resistant to abrasion than cement alone. To this mixture is added sufficient mineral oxide pigment to give the colour tone required. It is important to notice that the same operation that water-proofs the surface gives it a lasting colour of any intensity desired.

This combination of utility and beauty for the Resto-Crete treatment of concrete has had a rather unexpected result that is of special interest to architects. One of the disabilities of monolithic concrete design has been the difficulty of obtaining clear and lasting arrises. This is particularly important in the modern style of architecture, in which straight lines and shadows play such an important part. The Resto-Crete treatment brings the arrises into relief in a way that is strikingly in contrast to the untreated concrete, and compares well with those building stones most notable for a sharp arris.

A good example of monolithic concrete thus made weather-proof as well as attractive in appearance is the new building of Associated Screen News in Montreal. The former building, put up 18 years ago, also of monolithic concrete but the dull grey of its surface has been distinctly unattractive, though eminently serviceable. In the
newing the same economy and enduring quality have been attained by the monolithic design, and to this has been added, at little expense, an exterior that will be extremely attractive. It is intended, by the way, to treat the old building with Resto-Crete shortly, when the present contrast in appearance of the two parts will disappear.

The new part of the Associated Screen News building on Western Avenue, Montreal, is in two sections, a monolithic concrete office and in the rear a structural steel and brick studio. The concrete structure is of concrete reinforced with welded beams, columns and floors. The floors and roof (which will constitute a floor when and if the building is made higher) were cast by the removable pan system. The floor of the studio is laid directly on the ground surface.

The walls of the studio have some interesting features. The brick is faced inside with 3" hollow haydite blocks. Inside this is vertical 2" furring at 3-ft. centres, then a chicken wire laid on top of the wire horizontal 2" furring at 16" centres. Over the chicken wire between the strips are laid pads of mineral wool, and over this is nailed Johns-Manville perforated Transite board, 3/16" thick. This gives the studio a perfect acoustical quality, as the sound waves, striking the transite board, are broken up by the perforations, behind which they are absorbed by the mineral wool. Mineral wool has the rare quality of "straight line" absorption, so that the sounds within the studio are neither echoed loudly from the walls nor distorted in tone. The Transite board and mineral wool constitute, of course, a fireproof wall.
