NECESSITY FOR WEATHERPROOFING

There is probably no more acute problem facing the building owner than that of weatherproofing. The reasons for this might be listed as follows:

1. The actual disintegration of the building. Offhand this may seem negligible when we think of the massive structures that are built nowadays, but the proof of the statement is witnessed by the great number of buildings showing efflorescence and spalling, and by the vast number of treatments which are offered on the market as panacées.

2. The loss of capital investment, due to deterioration shortening the life of the building.

3. Loss of rental income, due to unattractive appearance.

4. Increase in operating cost, due to greater heat loss through increasingly porous exterior surfaces.

5. Increase in interior maintenance cost, due to damage caused by penetration of water.

Therefore from the standpoint of both the investment and the return, a good weatherproofing job is a saving rather than an expense.

THE CAUSES OF WATER PENETRATION: DISRUPTION

If it were not for the excessive penetration of water we would not be faced with this problem. The presence of any or all of these conditions cause excessive penetration of water into masonry walls.

1. Structural cracks, and disintegration cracks and holes.

2. Most mortar joints, such as brick, stone, etc.

3. Porous surfaces such as limestone, sandstone, common brick, concrete, etc.

It is at once obvious that the penetration through all except structural cracks could have been prevented and can be treated. Structural cracks, however, are usually subject to further movement, and hence the treatment cannot be absolute, though the condition may be vastly improved by the use of suitable methods.

It appears, then, that practically all masonry surfaces will absorb moisture. This is due to the fact that they are composed of many differently shaped crystals, somewhat loosely packed together, whereas metals and glass are extremely dense. Under a microscope, concrete resembles more a mass of snowflakes in density, than the familiar structural mass to which we are accustomed. The voids seem to predominate over the solid matter. Therefore from the standpoint of weatherproofness, the only conceivable type of masonry unit which would be entirely weatherproof would be one with surfaces of the density of glass, and a structure composed of such a material would have to be entirely one unit with no joints, and no structural or other cracks.
Bearing this in mind for a moment, let us now look at the disrupting influences due to water penetration which cause deterioration of the building and which any treatment must withstand. Water causes disruption in four manners:

1. By carrying in corrosive chemicals which dissolve out important salts and deposit them on the surface, in the form of efflorescence. It is not generally considered, but air saturated with rain water carries the bases of the three most powerful acids known to chemistry, Hydrochloric, Sulphuric, and Nitric, and all will disintegrate masonry. Sulphuric acid is the most common, particularly where there is considerable coal smoke in the air. Salts of Hydrochloric acid such as common table salt are also present to some degree, particularly near salt water, and are able to generate this acid. Nitric acid is formed from the action of water upon millions of bodies of the so-called "nitrifying bacteria" which live in the air and are deposited upon masonry surfaces.

There are hundreds of other things which will also dissolve out the important salts in masonry, such as some of the mineral oils, blood, weak acids, alkalis or other chemicals in certain manufacturing processes, in the air, or perhaps in the masonry itself.

Water is the universal solvent, and consequently it is itself capable of dissolving out certain of these salts.

2. By expanding upon freezing. It is obvious that the minute water particles which are locked in a masonry mass will upon freezing exert a tremendous total pressure upon the internal structure of the mass itself; and the results are everywhere apparent as will be noted if one examines more closely the buildings around him.

3. By causing the extraneous growth of certain crystals. This is a physical process involving the addition of water to certain crystals with the resulting expansion of them. Calcium hydroxide is notable in this respect. Its crystals upon taking up water grow in one plane only, and the force released causes serious damage to concrete and other types of masonry.

4. By causing oxidation of steel reinforcing in concrete, etc.

It is interesting to note that the pressure released by crystal growth, including the formation of ice from water, may approach 14,000 Sq. In.

In addition to these types of disintegration, the use of soft aggregates in concrete in certain localities renders the building much more liable to the disrupting action of water.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR WEATHERPROOFING TREATMENTS

It is obvious, therefore, that the main objective of any weatherproofing treatment must be to permanently stop the ingress of water. It is believed that a material which will effectively accomplish this aim must fulfill the following specifications laid down more than 75 years ago by a group of scientists:

1. The material must penetrate easily into the masonry surface and remain there on drying.
2. The material must not concentrate on the surface so as to form a hard crust, but at the same time it must harden the surface sufficiently to resist erosion. (Obviously, therefore, the material must densify the existing surface by filling the holes, and must subsequently become hard).

3. The material must prevent the penetration of moisture, and at the same time allow moisture to escape.

(This may appear paradoxical, but if condensation water from the inside of the building which is drawn to the exterior of the building by the action of the sun is not allowed to escape, rotting of the masonry immediately behind the exterior surfaces will take place. This may take the form, among other things, of a crystalline growth as explained under Method 3, p.2. Or the rotting may be due to freezing of the condensation water so collected with the results described in Method 2, p.2. In the same manner that the human body must breathe to live, so also, masonry buildings must "breathe" to endure. It has been proven in research laboratories that air must be allowed to circulate throughout the masonry mass to prevent rotting; and what is more important, certain components of masonry must continually be exposed to the small amount of water vapor which is in the air to continue chemical processes necessary to the stability of the masonry as a whole. It was stated a while back that a material of the density of glass was the only material which would be entirely waterproof. Since it is impossible, however, to build a structure of such a material in one unit, structural cracks, cracks and holes between mortar and brick or tile, etc., and porous surfaces, are all of them bound to permit the entrance of water, and water from such sources must not be allowed to collect in the pockets, but must be allowed to evaporate freely from surfaces. Disruption due to the above conditions is usually noticed first where a water pocket has been formed by gravitation, i.e., where a great amount of water collects in the wall, such as below window sills or coping stones, at the ground level, and where other masonry masses butt into an adjoining wall).

4. The material must not discolor or in any way alter the original appearance of the surface.

5. The material must expand and contract uniformly with the surrounding surface so as not to cause flaking.

6. The material must be non-corrosive and harmless in use.

7. The material should retain its preservative effect indefinitely.

OLD WEATHERPROOFING METHODS

With the above objectives in mind let us now consider the various types of treatment on the market:

1. Oil paints, drying and non-drying oils. Oil paints commonly used have either standard fillers, or cement filler. Common drying oils used are China Wood Oil, and Linseed Oil, or combinations of these. Non-drying oils are usually mineral oils, or a combination of a mineral paraffin oil and any number of other oils.
The most important objection to these types of treatment is that they form a skin over the surface which does not permit water to escape from the wall, and therefore renders the structure liable to disruption of the type noted in spec. 3, p.3.

It is also true that no paint will form a perfect skin, but will leave numerous small holes and cracks visible under a microscope, which because of their physical form will allow moisture to penetrate more easily than to escape.

Most of the paints and drying oils in use are also subject to saponification due to the alkaline nature of masonry construction. Saponification causes them to "chalk", due to a chemical change in the basic oil which leaves it inelastic and rather soft (particularly in cement base paints, where free lime is present).

Paints and drying oils do not fulfill the objective from another standpoint — they do not densify the surface but merely bridge over the voids between the pinacles of solid material. Non-drying oils will often penetrate the surface for a distance but are apt to discolor it in so doing.

Of all these types of treatment, China Wood Oil is the least harmful, since it does not collect dirt, and will not cause disintegration of the masonry, but it does not fulfill the main objective.

2. Cement, Magnesite, and other paints and plaster coatings. These are non-elastic, and since they have a difference in coefficient of expansion from that of the surface upon which they are placed, are subject to the formation of a crack between themselves and that surface, and consequently soon peel off. Cement paints are usually apt to dust and shrink, due to the use of clayey admixtures to give flowability, to the use of too much water, and to improper curing. Magnesite, gypsum, sodium silicate, and glue base paints do not have in themselves inherent structural stability for exterior use.

It is obvious that these treatments do not fulfill the objective as regards densifying the original surface.

3. Waxes and Paraffin. There are two methods of applying these treatments, first, by reheating the surface and painting on the melted paraffin, reheating, and then wiping off the excess; and second, by dissolving them in solvents such as kerosene, turpentine, etc., and applying them directly, the solvent soon evaporating and leaving only the paraffin.

The effect of sealing the surface as is required by the first method has already been discussed; and with the second it is necessary to get a perfect skin if the treatment is to endure. Otherwise dust will collect in the pores and an opening for water be established. Now when it is realized that only about 10% or less of these solutions is paraffin, it is not surprising that microscopic examination reveals many minute holes through the skin, even after a number of successive treatments.

There are hundreds of possible combinations of this latter type, and the paraffin, or beeswax treatment is the oldest remedy known. However, no paraffin treatment fulfills the main objective.
It is obvious from the above that if any one of the various types of treatment herein enumerated completely fulfill the weatherproofing requirements, it would have dominated the market in the many years that it has been available for such use.

THE RESTO-CRETE SYSTEM

From the above discussion we may conclude that voids constitute a large part of the surface area of masonry structures. In developing a new material, therefore, the problem was to find a material which would simply fill those voids in compliance with the specifications enumerated above. After considerable research, pure Portland cement was chosen as the base, because in its hardened state its physical characteristics more nearly conformed to those of most masonry surfaces. To this was added a small amount of suitable chemicals to give waterproofness, sufficient expansion to lock the material in the voids, workability, and finally an inert material, which laboratory tests proved to be approximately 5% stronger than Portland cement alone, to resist abrasion.

The method of application on a suitably prepared surface consists of scrubbing on a regulated mixture of the material and water, and at the proper time rubbing it with clean rags to absolutely pack the material into the pores and to remove the excess. The colour of any porous masonry surface may be changed due to the fact that the largest portion of the surface area itself is voids, and to the use of high grade mineral oxide colour in the material with which these holes are to be filled. This method will not destroy physical and colour characteristics of limestone and sandstone surfaces.

The method has been developed to fit the individual requirements of all masonry surfaces which present a solid base. The list includes the surfaces of Cinder and Haydite block, concrete block, artificial stone, limestone, sandstone, porous granite, common brick, concrete, cement stucco, and granite; and mortar joints between all types of water-absorption, brick, stone, tile and terracotta. In addition a method of treating Cinder and Haydite block to produce a beautifully textured imitation Briar Hill Sandstone has been developed.

The material is made in eight standard colours and whites, and black, and special matching colours may be formed where necessary.

April 9th, 1927

Dear Sir:

When you were down here we could not find a sample of clogged pipe. Today I am sending a box containing short pieces. The worst is the one inch running from the main two inch line, to the girls wash and bath rooms. The other pieces will show you how the pipe becomes pitted and when the attempt is made to disconnect them, they brake.

During the last two weeks in March, we renewed the main line from the hot water tank through the laundry, out beyond the kitchen. These pipes were replaced with galvanized iron pipe, we should have done it with copper or brass. Next we had to do the pipe leading to the boys and girls bath rooms, etc. This we are doing with copper pipe. For material only the cost has been over one hundred and fifty dollars. It is only a matter of a short time till all the hot water pipes will have to be replaced.

For the past two years we have had trouble getting hot water. Both for the girls and boys baths we had to carry hot water from the laundry. While this is an improvement over what the Indian had in his own home, nevertheless with the crowd we have it makes a messy job and takes about every day of the week to see that every child has a bath once a week.

We also had to replace the top section of the hot water Jacket. If the cost of a hot water boiler with brass tubing were not prohibitive, we would have discarded the hot water jacket.
The jacket heaters are only guaranteed to thirty five pounds pressure and that is hardly enough to carry water to the top floor.

While we are on the subject of water, I might as well let you know that the water proofing on the outside front wall was not completely satisfactory. On November 22nd, and December 3rd, water poured in through the top of three windows. I suppose these people will be back to go over those sections. Other than in these places there has been no water, but in damp weather, the plaster continues to fall. One would expect that, as in many places the plaster is just holding and that is all. I hope the plaster was included in the appropriation for this year. The other parts of the walls are just as bad as the front, and the occasional rain storm causes the windows to leak. While repairing the Chapel after the fire, we had an easterly rain storm. Where the plaster and cork board was broken you could see the water trickling down on the inside of the tile wall.

In conclusion, I hope the Department will see a way to help us with renewing the hot water line and that the plastering will be repaired this summer. We cannot do any painting with the walls in the condition they are, and yet the other walls of class rooms, etc., are certainly in need of paint.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 21st, No. 51-0-5 concerning the waterproofing of the walls, and the letter of the Western Waterproofing Co. to you:

The Superintendent of the Company's Branch in Halifax, came to Shubenacadie on the train at 9.14 A.M. I was over in the village and arrived back at the school about 9.45 A.M. I told him the date and windows where the rain came in. As he was anxious to get the next train back to Halifax, he had only twenty minutes until train time. He stood on the granite base of the windows affected and looked up along the wall. Coming back inside he showed me where the mastic which he said had been disturbed by the storm windows, and said that the water could come in there. Of course that was not included in their contract. I never saw the contract and I told him I did not know anything about it, and that point should be settled between the Company and the Department. The place where the mastic was detached was near the bottom of the window and I suppose the rain would come in there, travel to the top of the window and then drop down. As for not seeing the water actually coming in, the few storms we had were during the night and I did not see the water coming in. But today we have had heavy showers with very little wind and the water came in one of the windows of the Community Room. Today on practically every window sill, the powdered plaster is falling. This may be what they would call condensation.

I suggest that you leave things for a while longer and see what happens.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

When making up your appropriation for next year's expenditures, we beg that you will consider the following:

1. Addition to the feed room, 30 X 14. When the barn was built ten years ago, there was no feed room, and a small space was taken from the implement shed for that purpose. As you know buying feed in small amounts is more costly than in carload lots. Further, the room is not rat-proof, and year after year, we have had considerable loss from these rodents. What we would like to see is space enough to handle a carload of feed, and have it lined with sheet metal to keep out mice and rats. A few years ago we managed from school funds to have such a room for flour, rolled oats, etc., and it has meant a considerable saving.

2. An addition to the hog house of 20 X 19, with a straw loft above. Some years ago you allowed $1000.00 for the hog house, a dairy, and an ice house. Later one hundred and Twenty-five Dollars ($125.00) was taken from that amount to do calking around the windows and doors of the school, leaving $875.00 for the two buildings. We kept within the amount but curtailed the size of the hog house. As it is now, we have no suitable place for butchering pigs, cows, etc. The last few years we have been buying our beef on the foot for the winter months. In order to butcher them, we have to take them a distance of two miles to a slaughter house. In that way we lose considerable time, and also lose valuable feed for the hogs. So if we had this addition to the hog house, it would enable us to keep more hogs, and have them and the beef butchered on the premises. The cost we estimate of such an addition, would be $450.00

The estimated cost of the addition to the feed room would not be above $275.00
This work we would do without any outside help, thereby giving the older boys a good opportunity to learn carpenter work. The last building done here was in 1935, when a residence was built for the assistant farmer.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of June 19 with reference to certain material required at the Indian residential school, Shubenacadie, N.S.

With regard to this inquiry I would point out that purchase requisition dated June 15 was forwarded to the Purchasing Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In reply to that part of your letter of June 15th, concerning the roofing shingles, these shingles are about three feet long and about a foot of depth. The weight is 240 lbs. to the square, or ten foot square. They are made in three weights, and we have asked for the heaviest, on account of such high winds in this locality. They are made by Brantford, and also by Barrett. They are the same as we have on the other barn, and most outbuildings. The cost is about $8.50 - $75 per square.

Hoping that this will clear up any misunderstanding we may have caused,

Lime-Spreading Attachment

Most soils require an application of limestone to grow either clover or alfalfa successfully. The lime-spreading attachment built especially for the No. 4-A manure spreader provides an economical and convenient way to spread limestone in quantities up to $3\frac{1}{2}$ tons per acre.

The lime-spreading attachment is easy to attach and just as easy to operate. There are two revolving disks with fins set side by side underneath the rear end of the spreader bottom.

When the spreader is in motion, the disks rotate and spread the lime toward the rear and produce an approximate spread of 12 feet. The steel retarder rack included as part of this attachment is placed at the rear of the spreader to keep steel prominent from breaking up the lime before it is dropped on the disks below.

The endgate is equipped with hangers which slip over the top of the steel retarder rack and hold the endgate in place while the load is being hauled to the field. The No. 4-A manure spreader has a capacity of two tons of limestone per load.

Endgate Attachment for Semiliquid Manure

The liquid portion of the manure is the most valuable part and should be carefully conserved. The endgate attachment is used in hilly sections to prevent waste when hauling semiliquid manure to the fields. It can be conveniently raised from the seat while the spreader is in operation. A semiliquid box rear pan for catching the semiliquid manure may be used either with the endgate attachment or alone where a minimum of litter is used.

Re Accident involving Shubenacadie Residential School Car - March 1942

Dear Mr. MacInnes,

I regret to report an accident involving damage to the above car while being driven by myself.

On returning to Shubenacadie by train from New Glasgow on Feb 24th I received Head Office letter of Feb 17th requesting me to complete an inspection of the Yarmouth Agency. To reach Yarmouth by train it involved my proceeding during the evening to Halifax or Windsor Junction for overnight then getting the Yarmouth train the following morning and...
spending eleven hours before reaching there with a similar time required to return to Shubenacadie.

My business here was completed, as far as possible for the day, by noon on the 26th and rather than lose one and one half days in reaching Yarmouth, and a similar delay to return, I requested the use of the School car from Father MacKay to which he gladly agreed.

I reached Yarmouth during the evening of the 25th, completed my inspection during the 26th and until 3 pm. on the 27th at which time I started for Shubenacadie via Shelburne and the South Shore Highway. This highway was taken as the Valley Highway via Kentville was blocked with snows.

On leaving Yarmouth, driving conditions were good with mild weather prevailing. At a point 5 miles before reaching Liverpool at a fairly close
turn in the road, a sheet of ice caused the car to skid sharply to the right. A row of guard rails banked the highway at the turn and the right-hand side of the car was grazed heavily by one pole while a second pole was struck by the left front of the car. The impact was fairly heavy with considerable damage being done. No other cars were near at the time. The car did not leave the highway and was not injured. I was driving alone.

I had the car towed to Thompson's Garage at Liverpool and proceeded, by bus the following morning to Halifax. At Halifax I visited the Nash Auto Sales Service and instructed them to send a truck to Liverpool to tow the car to their garage for repairs. I might add there are not any Nash Service Garages nearer than Halifax - it appeared obvious that this company at Halifax have the best equipment and mechanics to complete the necessary repairs. The Nash Service Garage at Halifax...
are distributors for Nash parts in Nova Scotia and are known to Father MacKay as reliable. The car was purchased from this company.

I have instructed this company to immediately submit an estimate of the cost of repairs and to proceed with same having in mind that the car is required at the School and should delay where difficulty might be experienced securing necessary new parts.

My driving speed at time of accident was 35 to 40 miles per hour and it happened at dusk just prior to shifting head lamps. Road conditions up to the time of meeting the sheet of ice were reasonably good with highway clear of snow although in parts wet & slushy.

I much regret having to report this accident to the School Car as it is my first after many years of driving Department cars. Yours very truly,

W.E. Cunliffe, Inspector.
March 7, 1942.

Dear Mr. Arneil:

I have received your letter of March 4 in which you report an accident involving the Shubenacadie Residential School car. The question of the repairs to the car is being dealt with on another file.

I am sorry to learn of this accident but also very glad to know that you were not hurt in any way.

With best wishes,

Yours sincerely,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

We are having a heavy rainstorm today, and on every window on the front of the school, we have pots and pans to catch, and sheets, etc., to absorb the rain that is coming in, dripping, almost running, from the tops of the windows.

Seven years ago this coming Fall, the Department had the front of the building, and part way around each corner, water-proofed. For a few years everything was fine; for the last two years a little rain has been coming in, but now it just pours in. During a storm less than a week ago, we had the same thing happen. It just means, that besides the mess, and the unpleasant smell of wet lime, that the plaster crumbles, and finally the putty coat lets go, leaving the brown undercoat.

We feel that until the war is over nothing can be done about it, not only on account of the cost, but more so the matter of obtaining the workmen to do a good water-proofing job. The flashing which goes partway under the granite coping on the top of the wall is partly to blame, but there is no doubt about it, that with a strong wind blowing the rain comes through the cement between the bricks, and also penetrates some of the soft bricks than can be found in the wall.

Seven years ago a goodly number of bricks were replaced, but apparently not all the soft ones were removed. A suggestion had been made that the copper flashing should cover completely the top of the wall.

The situation is not unusual in the Province, as practically every brick building erected in the Province for the past twenty-five years has had the same trouble.

We are calling the matter to your attention now only that it may be repaired at the convenient time.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, Nova Scotia.

With reference to your notation of May 10th last on copy of Dr. McGill's memorandum of May 7th regarding the above institution, I might say that as Mr. Buck was not in the Maritimes this summer he did not make the examination requested. However, you will recall that Mr. Sparks visited the Eskasoni and Shubenacadie Reserves in connection with the water supply question, and while at Shubenacadie he undertook an examination of the Residential School.

Mr. Sparks has reported that he found the situation as regards leaks when southerly and easterly storms occurred was as described in letter from Rev. Father J.P. Mackey, Principal, to Dr. McGill under date of May 4th last, and that considerable damage is being done to plaster work throughout the building, but principally on the top floor. The roof was examined and appeared sound, and it is considered no leakage could be attributed to this source.

As pointed out by Rev. Father Mackey in his letter of May 4th, it is not unusual in coastal areas for masonry buildings to have trouble of this nature. It will be noted further that Rev. Father Mackey states that some years ago the front of the building was waterproofed, and for a few years everything was fine. However for the past two years conditions have been getting worse again.

Mr. Sparks reports that all exterior wall areas and window and door openings were examined, as well as the roof parapet walls and copings. Leaks do not appear to develop under ordinary rain conditions, but only when storms occur. Under these circumstances, and in view of the conditions of the walls as noted during examination, it is Mr. Sparks' opinion that further waterproofing of walls and openings should be undertaken. He further considers that all exterior walls of the structure should be treated as considerable deterioration was noted in masonry previously untreated, as well as around window and door openings.

While Rev. Father Mackey advises he feels that until the war is over nothing can be done about repairs it would appear that much damage to the building may result if such repairs are postponed indefinitely. We therefore suggest that approval be given to arranging with a competent waterproofing company for an estimate of the cost of treating the exterior walls of the institution in order that consideration may be given to the possibility of undertaking some repair work at an early date.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch

Dear Father Brown:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to the washing machine at the Shubenacadie Residential School. To replace this equipment at the present time would involve an expenditure for which no special provision was made in the current year's appropriation. While at certain times of the fiscal year we are able to handle unforeseen expenditures, it is difficult to do so at present, due to the fact that the end of the fiscal year will soon occur and our funds at this period of each fiscal year are usually very low and all allotted.

If you had found it possible to come to Ottawa last month we could have discussed with you a number of matters with which you cannot be expected to be familiar at the present time. May I point out the following:

1. The fiscal year starts on April 1 each year and runs for a period of twelve months to the following March 31.

2. The estimates for the expenditure during each fiscal year have to be prepared several months in advance. For instance, the estimates for the fiscal year 1944-45, which begins on April 1, 1944, and ends on March 31, 1945, were prepared in October, 1943.

3. We are only allowed a very small amount to cover unexpected expenditures and, as a result, it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to provide funds unless the expenditure has been specifically provided for in the appropriation.

Rev. J.W. Brown,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
4. We always provide the per capita allowance without any request from the school, because this is a regular expenditure each year and, without any communication from the principal, we know the pupilage for which grant is provided and the rate per capita.

5. When funds are provided for an expenditure purchase is made through our Purchasing Branch and they require very detailed information regarding the articles required, in order to make certain that they secure what is actually needed.

At the present time I cannot see my way clear to purchase a new washing machine for the Shubenacadie School and I trust that you can arrange to have minor repairs made that will keep this machine in operation for the next few months. Although we have not been previously advised regarding the condition of this machine and, therefore, have not provided any amount specifically in our 1944-45 appropriation for its replacement, we will endeavour to find funds in May or June. This will involve reducing the amount to some other residential school and such procedure always causes us considerable correspondence, if not rather strong protests.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

We have been given to understand that all reports and purchases, other than minor, must be submitted at once, to be considered in near future appropriations for school. I am therefore submitting report of Mr. Macleod, our carpenter-engineer.

The pumps here were installed in 1929, consisting of:
- Only 5000 gal. per hour pump, driven by 1 - 5 H.P. Motor;
- Only 2500 gal. per hour pump, driven by 1 - 3 H.P. Motor.

These pumps have been running on an average of eight to eleven hours per day, for the last fifteen years. The pumps start against direct water pressure, cut in at full speed, with no air chamber or varying speeds to cushion strain on same. It is a case of start or break, which we have had plenty of in crank shafts and piston rods. The pumps being out of date, it is impossible to get parts, and we have to revert to brazing, which is not at all satisfactory for running parts.

The Commutator on armature of 5 H.P. Motor is completely worn out, has been refaced several times; not stock enough for further refacing.

We have two pressure tanks in pump house, and the pressure is maintained by pumps. We have no storage tank or reserve supply at all. If anything goes wrong with pumps, we are out of water completely until repairs are made. The voltage is irregular here, causing heating and wear on motors.

Would suggest new pumps, and one 5 H.P. Motor; otherwise water supply is going to be some problem shortly.

Leaks in hot water pipes are continuous. The minerals in the water when heated eat right through the pipes and fittings. Some of the pipes have been replaced four times in the last fifteen years. The only remedy here would be copper piping or water softener; the latter not satisfactory under supply conditions.

Kelvinator was condemned four years ago by reliable repair man.

All Motors and machinery are worn, which can only be expected after fifteen years.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Re: Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

Further to information already furnished you on the above, you are advised that the building was inspected by a representative of Messrs. Creaghan & Archibald, Montreal, Agents for the Western Waterproofing Company, in March of this year. This firm had carried out waterproofing on portions of exterior walls and stone copings about seven years ago which eliminated leakages into the building for some time, but it has been reported by the School Principal that for the last two years water has again been finding its way into the interior of the building, and is causing extensive damage to plasterwork.

Examination of the roof by Mr. Sparks in the fall of 1943, indicated that the roof covering was intact and that walls and parapet flashings were sound, but that bed joints below, and vertical joints between the coping stones, were in most cases only filled with broken and loose mortar, permitting water to seep down through voids in the wall between the brick facing and tile backing. Mr. Sparks expressed the opinion that water is also penetrating the brick facing of the wall. The total accumulation of moisture is being expelled at the heads and jambs of doors and windows resulting in the damage referred to.

Reporting on the failure of their previous treatment of wall surfaces, Mr. T.C. Creaghan stated that, in his opinion, water admitted at the top of the wall had destroyed adhesion of the waterproofing, and that before further waterproofing would be effective caulking should be repaired. He stated further that he did not believe any asphalt pointing compound would be able to resist constant expansion and contraction, and that for permanent satisfaction, the stone coping should be metal covered. While an estimate had been requested for the work considered necessary, none was received from this firm. We concur in their opinion, however, that caulking the joints of the coping with an elastic asphalt compound, would only be a temporary improvement and would have to be repeated at intervals, while for the permanent satisfaction could only be obtained by a metal covering being applied over the copings. The material used in the Shubenacadie area should be 16 ounce copper.

This Service contacted Mr. H.H. Foreman, Co-ordinator of Capital Equipment and Durable Goods, Wartime Prices and Trade Board, and was advised that 16 ounce copper would be released to the Contractor if it was decided to use this material.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10; Volume 6050, file 200-5, part 5)

It is likely that by installing a copper covering, much of the infiltration of water would be eliminated; but some waterproofing on the brick faces of the building would still be necessary. It is felt, however, that the latter phase of the work might be deferred until the effect of the metal covering could be observed. Mr. Sparkes was requested while in Nova Scotia to obtain competitive prices for the work involved, and was only able to secure a tender from one firm, namely: James Donohue, Limited, of Halifax amounting to $2,746. This firm carried out the roofing and flashing on the school building when it was built. Mr. Sparkes has advised they have a good reputation, that they have the necessary stock of 16 ounce copper, and would be able to give immediate attention to the work.

No prices have yet been obtained for waterproofing brickwork; but based on the cost of work carried out at the Louisbourg Museum some years ago at a unit price of 40 cents per square foot, applying a clear waterproofing compound to the affected areas, would require an expenditure in the neighborhood of $4,000. Due to wartime labour conditions, this unit price may no longer be applicable. Confirmation from a reliable firm would be necessary before funds were allotted to this phase of the work.

While no funds have been made available, it is possible that the Indian Affairs Branch may wish to proceed with some of the work in the near future, under which circumstances, it is recommended that the tender obtained by Mr. Sparkes, from James Donohue, Limited, amounting to $2,746., for applying the covering to the coping be accepted, and that $2,000. should be provided to cover the cost of the work and engineering expenses.

Instructions regarding our further action will be appreciated.

Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

In re: Proposed repairs to the Building.

James Donohue, Ltd., Halifax, N.S. were directed last November to undertake such repairs as would stop the roof leaks. For over three years, extra heavy rainstorms, from the south and east, have come through to the ground floor, damaging ceilings, walls, and floors.

Making another examination today, Mr. Donohue, and his crew man, with our Mr. McLeod, declares it is no use to go on with the copper repair work, ordered last Fall. Winter storms have so destroyed the roof, making many new leaks; thus, making utterly useless the proposed repairs.

What we need at once is a complete new roof job, and then the copper placed under the coping -- not over the coping, and down on to the leaking roof. That means all the granite coping must be removed, the copper placed or set on bricks, and then run down and under the new roofing, in such measure as to turn aside any water present from our severe wind and rain storms, coping then to be replaced. In our original plans, two inches of copper was directed to go under the roofing. There may be places where such would keep out the rain, but no good, on our hill, where the winds are strong. The old roofing has done its time at seventeen years, and is no longer a fit covering, to protect the building, or health of teachers and children.

The cost for proposed repairs was to have been paid from "House Money" the savings in seventeen years by Father Mackey and Sisters, for replacements in machinery within the building and on the farm.

Now, this proposition is entirely new and a much greater cost. May I suggest that it is a Capital expenditure and that our "House Money" should not be now expected. However, it is Department Money, and may be placed in its spending as the Department may direct.
The Repairs to the building has been on the Order Sheet for over three years. If longer delayed it will mean a major cost for repairs to the main building.

May I ask that some very definite action be undertaken at once.

If the Department thinks an Architect should visit and investigate roof conditions, may I suggest someone who knows of our maritime winds and rainstorms? Be that as it may, I hope for some early results; as all too hurriedly our fall storms will be our visitors.

I beg to enclose Mr. Donohue's estimate of cost for new roofing, and cost of copper work would be much less than former price submitted.

Yours very truly,

SHUBENACADIE, NOVA SCOTIA

The Contractor shall visit the site and make himself thoroughly familiar with existing conditions at the building. The work under this heading shall include all material, labour, equipment and services necessary for the proper carrying out of the work as shown and specified.

EXTENT OF WORK

The present felt and gravel roofing over the entire building is to be removed, and a new four-ply felt and gravel roof installed. The Contractor shall arrange that the roofing work be carried out in sections, so that at no time shall any portion of the roof be left unsealed. He shall arrange for the proper storage of new material and the removal of all surplus material from the present roof, and from the premises. He shall satisfy himself that the roof decking is smooth, rigid, and free from loose or rotten boards, or large cracks or knot holes. The deck boarding shall be broom clean before application of the new roofing. Any defective boarding in present roof deck shall be replaced with sound material.

The present coping stones of entire building (except over projecting higher portion at centre front) and the first outer course of brick immediately under the coping shall be removed, to allow setting of the new flashing. This work shall be done in sections, so that no unfinished portion of the wall be left exposed to the weather.

New copper flashing to be installed, running through wall under coping and outside course of brick. Existing flashings to be re-used, and additions and adjustments made to complete the work as indicated on the detail drawings. Existing flashing at chimneys, skylights, roof traps, junctions of lower roofs, ventilators, hoppers, etc. shall be repaired and adjusted as may be found necessary.

REMOVAL AND RESETTING OF GRANITE COPING AND BRICKWORK

The granite coping stones, and the outer course of brick immediately under, shall be removed to allow for setting the copper cap flashing as shown by detail drawings. This work shall be done in small sections, so that no part of the uncovered wall shall be left exposed to the weather. Clean off all loose mortar, and reset flashing, brick course, and copings in non-scaling cement mortar thoroughly bedded and all joints flushed full. All joints of coping stones shall have inside edges jointed, and exterior joints colored and finished to match existing work. The upper five courses under coping to be rejoined to match existing work.
The vertical joints in raised central front portion of coping where the coping and projecting ornament has not been removed and vertical joints at rise in coping over front end bays, and at chimneys shall be raked out to a depth of 1/8" and repointed with lead wool driven firmly into joints and finished flush.

FLASHING

Contractor shall supply and set all new cap flashing under coping stones and brickwork as shown by details. All new flashing and replacements to existing flashing shall be 16 ounce cold rolled copper properly lapped and soldered according to standard practice. Flash joints where copper and stone or copper and brick adjoin are to be thoroughly sealed with mastic caulking compound. At all points where roof is broken by chimneys, skylights, roof traps, junction of lower roofs with walls, ventilators, hoppers, etc., shall be repaired, adjusted, and renewed.

FELT AND GRAVEL ROOFING

Present felt and gravel roofing over all flat roofs of building shall be entirely removed, and new felt and gravel roofing installed. Contractor must arrange to carry out this work in such a manner that the interior of the building is protected at all times from the weather.

New roofing shall be four-ply built-up asphalt roofing with fifteen year guarantee bond, laid in accordance with the specification of, and inspected by an approved roofing manufacturer - Barrett Company Limited, or equal.

GUARANTEE BOND

The Contractor shall be required to furnish the Department with a 15 year Guarantee Bond, at the completion of the contract, covering material and workmanship in the installation of felt and gravel roofs.

GENERALLY

The Contractor must arrange to carry out the work so that the activities of the school may be carried on without interruption. All debris from the roof must be lowered to the ground in chutes, or in such a way as to minimize dust. The Contractor shall make good any damage to the building or grounds caused by the alterations.

The large tractor, purchased as a used tractor, is also giving out, and requires continual repairs.

Now for the big one!

We have had four weeks of hardship in our home, never experienced before. Our new pumps were placed and were efficient. All went well for a week, and then we lost the water, and have had to draw it for every house service for nearly a month. It seemed that the check valve in the main intake, 5 inch pipe, had failed. Our pumps had no prime and we could get no water. We dug up about 125 feet of pipe, including that which was out in the lake. We discovered the check valve twenty feet from lake side, and made repairs. In lifting the pipe, one connection was broken, and it took three weeks to replace the pipe, and make it water tight again. We got water on again last Saturday, October 13th, which, mostly, was an answer to prayers. I am forwarding samples of small fixtures, adhering to the interior of the main pipe. In some are pea sized holes; that same sized hole is in the pipe -- chemically eaten out -- leaving our main line pipe with a million chances to eat through, -- then the air gets in and our pumps stop. If that happens before Spring, we will be in a desperate plight. We are just going to hope and pray for the best -- that it may at least last until Spring.

The pump men and others agree there is only one solution - namely, a new pipe line from lake to school; and -- the pumps placed at the lake, not half way up. You can push water anywhere; it is most difficult to haul it up.

May I respectfully suggest that this work of replacement may simply not be set aside, cared for in the Spring, or "the Dept. has not enough funds to care for such coots" We cannot live here without water; we just must have it, and the Department will, I Hope, arrange for the work of replacement, so that it may be undertaken at any date, if it was so required.

October 18, 1945.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With report of costs going along to the Department, it is a good time to report conditions over our property, and suggest one most urgent and costly repair.

Our roofing repairs are being carried on as directed. Repairs to cracks, not included in specifications, will be cared for while the men are on the job. We hope to have a waterproof building, and can begin the interior repairs to ceilings and walls brought on by years of delay in undertaking the present repairs.

In general, may I suggest that all our units are going wrong, breaking up and blowing out, at quite the same time.

In 1945 we had to renew our boiler, at a cost of $590.00 which provides hot water and steam for the laundry. It just simply quit. We forwarded it to Matheson Co., New Glasgow. No repairs possible, and I ordered a replacement. Same is on duty now.

Again, the large house storage hot water boiler just went bad. It opened up enough to make repairs impossible. The condition of the boiler plate is such that - through chemical internal destruction - the whole unit is ready to quit any moment. We had the Matheson Co., Engineer come, measure the old boiler, and I ordered a replacement at a cost of $375.00. The small boiler for house hot water is a wreck, and will have to be renewed very soon.

I wish to advise also, that thousands of feet of piping through the building, hot water or steam, is in poor condition, and should be renewed with some other more resisting pipe.

The shingles on the barn had to be renewed at a cost of $349.00. We had a guarantee of fifteen years good service. The Company replaced the shingles at a considerable reduction in cost. This just had to be cared for in July, since Mr. Parker declared it was no good to put hay in the barn with the shingles in such condition.

SHUBENACADIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL -

This institution is one of the best managed schools that I have yet inspected. The Sisters in charge are competent teachers. The discipline is good, the children are well-behaved, well-dressed, and well-fed. I inspected the repairs that were being done to the roof. The stone coping was being lifted and replaced on a copper sheeting that would deflect the water off the wall. The workers were doing a good job, and I feel certain these repairs will prevent the water from seeping down the walls. The walls that were damaged will have to be replastered in some places, and then the damaged areas redecorated. Father Brown informed me that he had ordered - by express - seven lengths of 5 inch pipe, 18 feet long, to replace damaged pipes in the water system. Repairs were made without the new pipe. The seven lengths have arrived and are at the Shubenacadie Station. I am of the opinion that Father Brown was too hasty in ordering the pipe - especially asking that delivery be made by express. The cost of express, I understand, is approximately $35.00.

Father Brown has purchased, at different times, two - five acres of farm land adjoining the school property for $200.00 and $750.00, respectively, with the registering of the deeds in his own name of approximately $1,200.00. Again I must condemn Father Brown for his hasty action. I consulted Father Mackay, the former principal, on the need of this additional land. He advised that the school could undoubtedly get along for many years without the additional ten acres of farm land; but with it there would be twenty acres of land for root crops which would make it possible to raise five acres each year on a four-year rotation plan - which is necessary. Consideration should be given to the purchase of this ten acres from Father Brown. Note, vegetables have been grown on this land during the past year and, I understand that Father Brown has been paid, or expects to be paid, $75.00, for the use of the land this year.

Memorandum:

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School Water Supply.

With reference to your request of the 12th instant for an inspection and report on the above as asked for by memorandum dated October 31st addressed to you by the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Engineer R. R. Ross, of this Service, advises that he looked over this system when he was in Shubenacadie recently in connection with the Indian Agency Development.

The water system supplying the Residential School was installed in 1929 and consists of a 5 inch suction main approximately 1150 feet long from a lake north of the school farm to a pump-house located on the farm and a 4 inch pressure main approximately 750 feet long from two 1100 gallons Hydro Pneumatic pressure tanks in the pump-house to the school. The pump-house is about 14 feet above the level of the lake and there is an additional rise of about 15 feet to the school. Approximately 425 feet of the suction main at the lake is on property held by the adjoining land owner and the right to construct and maintain the main is covered by an agreement dated October 22nd, 1929. Besides the tanks, the equipment in the pump-house consists of two reciprocating pumps, renewed during the past summer, of capacities of 1500 and 3500 gallons per hour respectively at 100 pounds pressure. These pumps are electrically driven with a gasoline engine stand-by and are automatically controlled to maintain water under pressure in the tanks.

The piping is of galvanized steel and when dug up during the fall, to replace the foot valve in the lake, were found to be extensively pitted under tubercles on the inside. The pipe was not only then cut and lined with lead but some tubercles with adhering flake of metal that had been removed were examined and these verified the description of corrosion as given by the farm foreman making the repairs. Although galvanizing was not noticed on the outside of the pipes when they were dug up, no serious exterior corrosion was found.

It appears that the corrosion of the pipe has reached a critical depth and at any time the pitting may extend through the metal which is about 1/4 inch thick. Since this is a suction main, or intake, any leakage will deprive the pumps of

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

(over)
their prime which amounts to seven or eight hundred gallons in this length of pipe. With the pumping system out of order not only is the Residential School without water, but water under pressure is essential for the furnaces.

Under the circumstances it is recommended that the intake main from the lake to the pump-house as well as the pressure main from the pump-house to the school be renewed during the coming summer at such time when the existing system is not operating. It is considered that cast iron pipe should be used for this purpose on account of its non-corrosive qualities. Since 4 and 6 inch sizes are standard for cast iron pipe, it is recommended that 6 inch be installed for the suction main instead of 5 inch as at present and the present size of 4 inch retained for the pressure main.

Regarding the suggestion to remove the pumps to the lake it is understood the pumps in their present location gave satisfactory service in the past until the foot valve failed through corrosion. It is felt that with an intake main without leakage the system will continue to operate satisfactorily as presently laid out. The land at the lake is not owned by the Department and the pump-house at this location would be farther from the other buildings for operation and electric service.

An estimated cost for carrying out this work is given as follows:

| Materials | $2,600.00 |
|-----------|------------|
| Excavation, backfill and laying pipe | $2,050.00 |
| Contingencies | $350.00 |
| **Total** | **$5,000.00** |

It is suggested that the materials be ordered at as early a date as possible in order that they may be on hand to replace the present system early in the spring should failure take place during the winter. The distances given above are only approximate and it is suggested the Reverend Principal of the school be asked to check the distance between the inlet of the main and the pumps and also between the pumps and the school before an order for pipe is placed.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

Further to information furnished in our memorandum of September 12th last, dealing with the domestic water service, and moisture infiltration at the above School, you are advised as follows:

Under date of September 13th this office suggested to Mr. Ross that since no estimate of cost had been included in his report, it would be well to contact a reliable plumbing and steamfitting firm and obtain an estimate of cost for the work. At the same time we advised him that we were requesting the Canadian representatives of the Western Waterproofing Company, in Montreal, to arrange for an inspection of the exterior walls by their local representative, and to furnish him with their recommendations and an estimate of cost for waterproofing treatment. We have been advised in the interim between our memorandum of September 13th and the present, by the distributors, that the introduction of Cactizone into the domestic hot water system does not eliminate the need for water softening equipment, but merely prevents solidification of deposits on the piping of chemical elements present in the water. Final consideration of the matter must, therefore, include water softening equipment.

Under date of October 8th last, we received a letter from Messrs. Creaghan and Archibald, of Montreal, Canadian representatives of the Western Waterproofing Company, stating that they had inspected the School, had taken numerous photographs, and were preparing to study the problem, with a view to recommending procedure to be followed, and the preparation of an estimate of cost for the work. Mr. Ross had suggested to them that, upon completion of their study, one of their officers should visit our Chief Architect and present their findings with consent of their executive of Messrs. Mr. Buck. In their letter Creaghan and Archibald indicated they would follow this action but, to date, this Service has not been contacted. Such work is slow and costly and we must be prepared to receive an estimate of considerable proportions. We will contact Messrs. Creaghan and Archibald regarding the matter very shortly and report their recommendations, and estimate of cost to you for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Under cover of a letter dated November 6th, Mr. Ross has furnished us with consent and a tender, resulting from an examination of the domestic hot and cold water system, by W. J. Christie, Plumber and Steamfitter, of Truro, Nova Scotia, involving an expenditure of $8,300. Mr. Christie confirms our opinion that most of the water piping is not only corroded but is also so filled with encrustation that a severe drop in pressure is occurring on the upper floor. He also recommends, however, removal of certain pieces of equipment, and replacement of many plumbing fixtures, regarding which we have had no previous complaint or report.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

(over)
Our preliminary study of the mechanical services in the School indicates that some of the present equipment could be retained with advantage, but we are doubtful if any reliable opinion could be obtained without sending our Mr. Hargreaves to Shubenacadie to inspect the system and to submit a report.

In a brief discussion of the situation at this building between our Chief Architect and Mr. Phelan, in which the likelihood of an emergency developing was pointed out, the latter officer of the Indian Affairs Branch indicated that it was not likely that any funds for work on the Shubenacadie Residential School would be included in their 1947-48 estimates.

Under such circumstances, we do not propose taking further action, other than reporting on comment from Creaghan and Archibald, unless requested to do so.

Dear Sirs:

In answer to your communication of September 15/46 and with reference to interview which the writer and our Mr. Pleckan had with your Mr. Buck in Ottawa on January 10th., we wish to submit the following proposal for weather-proofing all exterior walls (exclusive of stuccoed passageway) of the complete building referred to above from roof flashing down to grade on all elevations.

Scope of Work:

1. After thoroughly washing down the surfaces we would apply one coat of iron waterproofing over all surfaces of the brickwork applied by brush. This iron would form a bond between the masonry and cement coats which are later referred to and would also give a more even density of surface over the areas so that any water taken out of the cement plaster coats would be evenly distributed. This iron coat would be allowed to oxidize thoroughly before any further operation takes place.

2. The next operation would consist of the application of a base coat of cement and sand containing a small percentage of iron bonded to the iron waterproofing coat. This coat would be scratched and approximately one-quarter inch in thickness.

3. A final cement finish coat would then be applied and wood floated to true surface of a maximum thickness of one-quarter inch.

4. A further and final application would consist of brushing two coats of our Resto-Crete Weatherproofing treatment over all surfaces of a colour to suit the client. We believe that a pure white colour might be very suitable for this purpose but that is a matter of choice.
Continued:

5. All stonework would be repointed and weatherproofed with Resto-Crete.

6. We also include for checking over all openings and resmilking same using mastic placed by gun.

In quoting the figures as below mentioned we assume that the owners would supply us with the necessary water to allow us to carry out these operations.

For the work as above specified we quote a lump sum price of Thirteen Thousand One Hundred Dollars ($13,100.00) and assume that if this work were to be done that same should be started and completed during good weather periods.

Guarantee: We guarantee that if, at any time, within 5 (five) years from date of completion, it should happen that leakage develops in the surfaces treated by us, due to defective work on our part, we will upon request promptly make repairs thereto at our own expense. Defects in the structure, or other causes beyond our control, resulting in fracture, are not covered by this guarantee. Roof and roof flashings to be properly maintained by others during period of guarantee.

As mentioned to your Mr. Buck, if the base coat referred to under item No. 2 was applied under pressure by the use of a gunite machine the coat would be slightly harder. This would cost an additional Fourteen Hundred Dollars ($1400.00) due namely to getting a compressor and the equipment on the job with additional use of more material.

Memorandum

Re: Water Infiltration, Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie Indian Agency, N.S.

We have had in our hands since January 22nd, 1947, a proposal submitted by Messrs. Creaghan and Archibald Ltd., of Montreal, Canadian representatives of the Western waterproofing Co., of the United States, following a thorough inspection of the above school building carried out in company with our Mr. Ross, about October 1st, 1946.

You were advised in our memorandum of October 8th last, that Creaghan and Archibald, after a study of data assembled on the site, proposed having their Mr. Archibald visit our Chief Architect to discuss the matter before submitting a proposal. This visit and discussion took place on January 10th, 1947, following which the proposal referred to above was submitted.

As Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Indian Affairs Training Division had indicated that no funds for work on the building were to be included in the 1947-48 estimates, we have deferred reporting on the matter until the present, when time from more pressing commitments, could be found.

In the discussion referred to, Mr. Archibald stated that the condition at the school, was not an uncommon one in coastal areas in Canada, where violent storms occur resulting in great horizontal precipitation as vertical, hence sufficient force to drive water through brick jointing, and even through brick unless special precautions are provided for in specifications. Mr. Archibald as might be expected, recommends that cement containing water retarding lime should be employed in brickwork, which in turn should be laid by such specialist firms as themselves, who while limiting a guarantee of their own work to five years, consider such masonry construction to be completely satisfactory for the lifetime of the building. It is our opinion that this is advice well worth following, in coastal masonry construction.

Mr. Archibald stated that the brickwork at Shubenacadie appears to be as well laid as an average specification demands, and that while the cement mortar used, appears strong and hard, it gives definite evidence of shrinkage, leaving cracks at the vertical and horizontal edges of the joints. In our opinion this fault indicates a mortar containing too much cement and too little or possibly no lime. Even in cement mortar a percentage of lime paste is essential to retard moisture absorption by the brick, while the set and bond is taking place.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

In connection with your memorandum of December 2nd, 1946, to Mr. Hoey re the above, you are advised that our Mr. Hargreaves carried out an inspection of the domestic hot and cold water services on May 28th to 31st inclusive, and the following report is presented for your consideration and for the information of Indian Affairs.

Cold water from a lake is pumped into two pressure tanks located in a pump house and then pumped to the building through a 4" cast iron pipe. At the point of entry to the building this line is reduced to a 2" and is run in black steel pipe to the boiler room equipment and to the distribution system. The distribution mains are progressively reduced as they are connected to the various fixtures and risers.

Domestic hot water is heated through a boiler-the-water-line type of heater connected in series to both low pressure heating boilers. There is also a jacket heater, originally intended for summer service. All the foregoing equipment was installed originally. The storage tank has been replaced within the last year due to the failure of the original unit.

The water, while potable and certified by the Dominion Analyst as being satisfactory for human use, has attacked all the black and galvanized steel pipe and as a result a heavy formation of sludge which has been analyzed as containing 85% iron oxide, has almost completely clogged the lines. This has retarded the flow to a mere trickle on the upper floor and in a small amount of water permitted to reach the lower floor and basement fixture. On both floors the pressure is raised to an abnormal level of 50 to 60 p.s.i.d., in order to serve bath tubs on the top floor. This is done at the risk of a major collapse of the mains and risers. On occasions, some pipes have burst, resulting in flooding of certain areas. Normal pressures not exceeding 40 p.s.i.d. are necessary if the fixtures and taps are to be protected against damage. Some branches have been replaced with copper pipe, and an examination showed these lines to be entirely free of sludge and scale.

The heater was disconnected and found to be completely blocked and 3" pipe connections between the heater and tank were examined and found to be plugged with sludge so badly that a pencil could hardly be inserted.

In short, it can be definitely stated that the entire distribution system within the building including risers, is in a hopeless state and is in need of complete replacement.

Non-ferrous piping should be used in the re-design, and it is recommended that type K hard drawn copper be used for the mains with streamlined copper branches and risers.

J.M. Hardie, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 26 November, 1947.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 13th November, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That under Vote 181 of the 1947-48 estimates of the Department of Mines and Resources, funds have been provided for repairs and replacements to the domestic hot and cold water system now installed in the Indian Residential School, at Shubenacadie, N.S.;

That tenders were invited, on the basis of drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, by an engineer of the Engineering and Construction Service of the Department;

That bona-fide lump sum tenders were received from the parties and for amounts as follows:

W.J. Christie, Esq., Truro, N.S. $7,250.00
Roscoe Schofield, Esq., White Rock, N.S. $8,007.00
Edwin H. Campbell, Esq., Truro, N.S. $8,132.59
J.A. Moulton, Esq., 15 Clifton St., Halifax, N.S. $8,900.00
J.D. Barrett, Esq., Truro, N.S. $10,546.46

That the tenders were analyzed and found to be in accordance with the drawings, specifications and tendering documents prepared by the Department;

That with provision for contingencies and supervision the acceptance of the lowest tender would entail an approximate total expenditure of $8,000.

As the work is considered to be of an emergency character, the Minister recommends that he be authorized to accept the lowest tender, as submitted by W.J. Christie, Esq., Plumbing and Heating Contractor of Truro, N.S., and to enter into a contract with him for the repairs and replacements required, in accordance with drawings and specifications prepared by the Department, and the Contractor's tender of $7,250 which, with provision for contingencies and supervision will entail a total expenditure of funds to the approximate amount of $8,000; the said expenditure to be met from the appropriate Votes of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

'Sgd.' A.D.P. Heeney,
Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

You recently forwarded to this office a copy of your memorandum of December 4th to Mr. Mills with reference to P.C. 4844 dated November 26th, 1947, authorizing acceptance of the tender of W.J. Christie for $7,250 for repairs and replacements at the above school.

Mr. Morris, Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies, has just returned from Nova Scotia and he was informed recently that the contractor is having difficulty in obtaining the materials he requires to carry out the work and consequently does not expect to start until some time in March. We are extremely anxious to have the work at the Shubenacadie Residential School completed at the earliest possible date, not only because the repairs are urgently required but the funds for the work are included in the current year's appropriation.

We would appreciate it very much if your Branch could give some assistance to the contractor in securing materials so that the necessary work may be completed before the end of March, 1948.

Bernard F. Henry
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Confirming what was said at that time, you are advised that there are no restrictions in effect on any materials the contractor is obligated to use in his work on the contract, and this Division can be of no assistance in expediting delivery of materials in short supply, for execution of a lump sum contract.

The following pages introduce a variety of tried and proven chopped meat formulas that will be of great assistance to the meat retailer who wishes to prepare from various meats cuts and sells, and trimmings. It is not suggested that the retail meat dealer merchandise at one time all the different chopped meat items in this book. It would be more satisfactory to select a few formulas in line with the meats that are moving slowly and from accumulated trimmings on hand.

Every formula should be tried out from time to time and the retailer can then concentrate on the ones that prove the most popular with the trade served.

It is important to keep in mind that a profitable volume of business cannot be built up permanently unless the buying public receives fresh, wholesome meat. Trimmings should be used only when fresh, and should not be allowed to accumulate or they may become tainted or discolored. An excellent idea to follow is every morning, or at least once each day, check the refrigerator and then plan chopped meat sales according to the cuts on hand that are available for sale.

The cost price of chopped meat, ready for sale, depends upon the quality of meat used, the amount of fat, and whether or not binders, seasoning, ice and water are used. The cost price should be determined at the time of making, taking into consideration the value per pound of the various materials used.

The formulas in this book are generally given in amounts up to 100 pounds of meat. These can be increased or decreased according to sales volume. Seasoning and binders should, of course, be used in proportion.

Where the less tender cuts, or combinations of different kinds of meat are used, best results and a more uniformly blended product will usually be obtained by chopping through the coarse plate first, then mixing thoroughly, and rechopping through the fine plate.

BINDERS

Binders (cereals or fillers) are used to bind or hold chopped meats together, and when used in sufficient quantities should be added to make mixing easy; they also hold the natural juices of the meat and absorb moisture. The addition of a binder improves the texture of chopped meat, making it compact yet smooth.

The principal binders in use are soya bean flour, corn flour, rice flour, potato flour, dry skim milk, crackers, dry bread, and blends of these and similar materials.

The cost of binders varies but per 100 pounds of meat averages about $6 and is governed by state regulations.

In certain localities the use of binders is prohibited unless there is a poster displayed which reads, "sausage with cereal added."

There are also weights and measures laws which govern the sale of food. In some localities, for example, it is not permissible to sell any meat by weight; it must be sold by the pound.

Every merchant should be familiar with all such laws and regulations and operate strictly in conformance with them.

FORMULAS FOR SPECIALTIES

In addition to display in bulk, chopped meats today are in increasing demand in "specialty" forms, such as loaves, rosettes, and patties.

CHOPPED BEEF ROSETTES

Chopped beef rosettes are made from lean chopped beef with the aid of a transparent tumbler or tea cup of a size that will hold about ¼ pound of meat. The meat is first chopped through the coarse plate. The fine plate is used for the second run to make the rosettes.

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School

We are in receipt of your letter of November 25th enclosing letter of the same date from Rt. Rev. J.P. Mackey, Principal of the above school, with reference to the financial situation.

Careful consideration has been given to the contents of both letters.

While we appreciate careful management, at the same time we feel that funds accumulated are intended to be used at a subsequent date for expenditures that would improve conditions for the pupils and that are not ordinarily provided by the Department.

During the war years when our appropriations were reduced, it was necessary to expect schools which had a surplus from previous years to use the funds for expenditures that possibly would have been supplied by the Department in ordinary years.

Mr. Phelan expects to be in Shubenacadie next week and will be prepared to discuss the whole situation further with Msgr. Mackey and yourself. He will bring the accounts with him.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

During the recent visit of Dr. H. L. KEENLEYSIDE, Deputy Minister of Mines & Resources, the situation at the captionally noted School was brought to his attention by the Principal, Rt. Rev. J. P. Mackey and myself.

In our informal discussion the whole financial situation was brought to light and in particular the matter of repairs to the building that was effected by using the School money. Mr. KEENLEYSIDE requested that a detailed account be submitted to you and a copy of the letter forwarded to him, in order that his memory be refreshed. This is being done and I would strongly recommend that if at all possible the School be re-imbursed for the major repairs and replacements which were made by using School funds.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

An inspection was recently carried out at the above school in connection with the completion of two contracts. Our inspecting officer furnishes comment on both contracts as follows:

(a) Domestic Hot and Cold Water Revisions -

Our officer met Mr. W.J. Christie, Plumbing and Heating Contractor, who has completed revisions and additions to the Domestic hot and Cold Water System at the school, and the work was carefully examined.

The installation has been carried out in a most satisfactory and workmanlike manner, and in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by this Division; and to the satisfaction of the school authorities and Indian Superintendent H.C. Rice.

Under the circumstances, we have accepted the work, and are returning the security deposit to the Contractor.

(b) Waterproofing Contract -

While our officer was in Shubenacadie, he inspected the waterproofing work carried out by Messrs. Creaghan and Archibald. Their Halifax representative Mr. Peitkin, under whose supervision this work was executed, reviewed all phases of the work with our officer, and explained, in detail, how the various operations included in the contract, were carried out.

The caulking around the window and door frames was carefully examined, and appeared to have been well done. The finish over the entire wall surface was put on under pressure, and it is evident that no pains were spared to make a thoroughly good job.

The colour is a medium grey, and some areas are slightly darker than the main surface. It was explained that this was due to varying weather conditions at the time the finish was being applied. The opinion was expressed, by Mr. Peitkin, that the weathering effect will ultimately result in a solid colour throughout. While the general appearance of the building is quite different from its original colour, it is not unpleasant.

Several severe rainstorms have occurred since this was completed, and there has been no evidence of any filtration of water through the walls. The Principal and Indian Superintendent H.C. Rice, both, expressed complete satisfaction. Under the circumstances, the work has been accepted and we are releasing the Contractor's security deposit.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

As you are no doubt aware, the firm of Creighton and Archibald, 1440 St. Catherine Street, West Montreal, P. Q., has recently completed a water proofing job on the captionally noted school.

During the last thirty-six hours we have had a very heavy rain accompanied with gales of wind force and as a result we find that the weather proofing job as performed by this Company is definitely not satisfactory. Along the whole western front of the building, numerous leaks appeared and it is felt that the remainder of the building is possibly in the same condition. The following telegram was dispatched to the firm in question:

"Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N. S. which your firm has recently completed water proofing leaking very badly and your immediate attention is requested."

Although we have not got the contract entered into with this Company, it is felt that this is a guaranteed job for a period of five to ten years.
May we be advised at your earliest convenience, what your wishes are respecting our further action at this point.

H. C. RICE, Superintendent,

Re: Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Reference to the weather proofing job recently completed at the captionally noted school and further to my letter of recent date respecting same.

On Sunday last, a Representative of the firm of Creighton & Archibald visited the Indian Residential School and went over the whole building. At the time, it was impossible for him to know exactly where the leaks were originating but requested that during the next severe rain storm, he be contacted at his Halifax headquarters at which time he will proceed to Shubenacadie in an effort to trace the leaks.

It should be pointed out that at the time the leaks appeared in this building, we were experiencing one of the worst rain storms in recent years, and it is quite possible that these leaks might not show up again for some time. However, the work is definitely defective to some degree and as it is a guaranteed job for five years we will see that the situation is rectified.

Due to weather conditions during the next few months, it will be impossible to carry on any work of this nature until Spring. However, should we have a severe enough rain to call this Representative, he will mark the leaks in order that his Company can proceed with the necessary alterations in the Spring.
Yours very truly,

H. C. RICE, Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency.
Ottawa, 20th January, 1949.

Dear Sir,

Paying a visit to some of the youngsters laid up with chickenpox, gave me an opportunity of inspecting the bed blankets. Needless to say they have been in use for many years and with washing and wearing they are very thin.

Our financial position being what it is, it is impossible for us to go out and replace these blankets. We understand that Supt. Rice has a large number of blankets from the War Assets.

Would it be possible that he might allow us one hundred and thirty-five, being one for each child? If Supt. Rice is to pay for them, could we have that number at the same price he is to pay for them?

The chickenpox will clear up in a few more days.

Very truly yours,

Rt. Rev. J. P. Mackey.
